Upon completing recon missions of several fires managed by a complex in a B206L4, the fuel truck driver noticed a small impact area on the underside of the tail rotor gearbox cowling. The impact area had numerous small cracks dispersing from the center. Because there were no chips or indentations, it appeared to be a bird strike. Probably a small bird, sparrow or robin. No indications of a bird strike were noticed during flight and no evasive maneuvers from birds were performed. The bird strike was unnoticed in flight. Upon discovery of the possible impact area, the pilot took pictures and forwarded them to the company director of maintenance and notified the helicopter manager and helibase manager.

We were dispatched to the xxx fire in an ASM configuration. After speaking to the IC and IC{T} to determine and sync objectives, strategies, and tactics we discussed the needed tools to achieve the objectives of perimeter control {Full Suppression} with the IC and IC {T}. The fire was burning during peak burn period, in a high elevation mixed conifer fuel type with a moderate to heavy dead and down component, low to moderate rate of spread {3-5 Ch/Hr}, moderate surface fire flame lengths {2-4 ft}, isolated to group torching {occurring every 4-5 minutes}, Primary residences in the vicinity {within 1 mile}, a State Highway within 1/2 mile, a small community within 2-3 miles, and a high resistance to control due to access and fuel type {bug kill in the area}. The dew point at KXXX was -2c indicating a dry air mass in the area. The following aircraft were recommended to the IC and IC {T} based on conditions, fire activity, time to complete the retardant line, etc: 2 additional SEATS {Total of 4}, 2 Large Air Tankers, and a VLAT. We determined that based on load and return times, anticipated lag time in getting aerial assets on scene, it would take 2 SEAT loads across the heel, 8 loads per flank {16 SEAT loads total}, and an undetermined number across the head depending on timing of aircraft. To reduce cumulative transference of risk to the flight crews, increase efficiency, increase probability of success , and allow for all aircraft to be made available in a short time period we made the decision to order the VLAT with the concurrence of the IC and IC {T}. We were fully anticipating needing to double the loads needed by the time the aircraft arrived on scene. The order was placed thru the appropriate dispatch center for all aircraft and we began to work the fire to achieve objectives. We had a very candid discussion with the IC and IC{T} that if we do not get the aircraft needed we need to revisit ``the plan`` as without the needed tools we would not be able to successfully meet the objectives and there for not expose the flight crews to a loosing proposition. Approximately 1 hour after beginning retardant operations we were informed that per the Duty Officer {DO}the VLAT has been canceled. We discussed the issue with the IC and IC{T} and informed them of the fire activity, shifting winds, doubling of fire size, load and return times, cost of retardant delivered by the VLAT, and attempted to give them the information they would need to discuss with their Duty Officer. They made a few phone calls and informed us that the DO wanted some time to think about it. We informed the IC that the retardant operation would be halted until a decision could be made and offered our assistance to the ground fire fighters. During these discussions the fire activity picked up and the fire again doubled in size and began to spot short range {3-4 ch}. Due to the unnecessary delay and limitation of tools we were being allowed to utilize we began to suspended air operations and returned to KXXX for fuel. Also, during this time the winds on the fire switched 180 degrees, exhibited signs of high atmospheric instability {Rotors and whirls from the column} and the fire began to out flank our retardant line and move toward H2 which was staffed with unburned fuel between them and the main fire. Based on the lack of support and winds we halted operations to reduce exposure to ourselves and the other flight crews and recommended that the crews on H2 reassess their LCES and consider hiking off the hill. Once on the ground we made contact with the IC and they were quite frustrated and apologetic, I told them that I understand it was not their issue and we would help them in anyway we could, both the IC and IC {T} were very appreciative. While on the ground at KXXX the fire activity again picked up and a moderate to well developed column developed on the left shoulder, visible from KXXX, we were contacted by dispatch that the IC needed us over the fire ASAP. We launched within 6 minutes and were on scene. As an aircrew, it is neither appropriate or acceptable to limit what tools an IHC crew can use to construct line, we provide them with task, purpose, and an end state and allow the professionals to make the determination on how to achieve it. The reverse should be true from the ground to the air. Cost shall not be the sole determining factor when deciding what ``tool`` to use to meet the stated objectives. As a result of the above listed factors we halted aviation operations due to an unacceptable level of attempted risk transference and changing conditions.

While conducting a review of the John Day Rappel Base the Region 6 Aviation Safety Manager visited with the Forest Service Single Engine Air Tanker (SEAT) pilot and manager; also stationed at John Day.  It was discovered that the Ayres Thrush, Model S2R-T45 was being operated without the use of aircraft performance charts developed by the aircraft manufacturer for firefighting operations.  Additionally when the SEAT is dispatched for a fire the local dispatch is not providing estimated drop area terrain elevations.Background:The RASM Council accomplished a SEAT risk assessment in October 2004.  One area identified operations at high density altitudes without performance charts as a hazardous activity.  The RASM Council recommended that SEATs not be used where performance data does not exist and forwarded this issue to the RAO Council.  The RAO Council made the following recommendations;•	Terrain elevation in the drop area is sometimes unknown on the initial response therefore, an estimate should be provided to the pilot on the dispatch order to allow computation of the allowable load. •	Pilots should be able to determine that a positive rate of climb (50 feet per minute) can be achieved on take off and to an altitude 1000 feet above the expected drop location at the response weight.•	Aircraft without performance information available to meet the contract requirement in B2.4.5 will not be allowed to operate on lands under FS protection.It appears these recommendations are not being followed at John Day.

Our Helitack crew purchased a brand new MARK V from Aerostat INC in early 2017. The machine was bench tested and seemed to operate properly. The machine was first used operationally on the Slim Fire in June 2017. The glycol pump was not functioning, the auger in the hopper unscrewed itself, and the agitator in the hopper was constantly crushing PSD balls. We contacted Aerostat and sent the machine back to be refurbished later that month. We received the PSD machine back in July. We benched tested in the fall and spring with no issues. We tried the machine again operationally on the Redondo RX in April 2018 and experienced more issues. Once installed in the helicopter, the PSD machine would trip the breaker. With further inspection we were able to find that the main motor on the PSD machine was not working. The water stored in the PSD machine had leaked and rusted the tools and the bottom of the PSD machine. Multiple electrical connections were loose and or needed to be re clamped and secured. The machine was once again sent back to Aerostat. We received the machine back in June 2018. When tested the wheel on the PSD machine was rotating in the wrong direction. We determined the main cord to the machine was wired wrong. We have yet to use the machine operationally.

Aircraft inspector xxxxxxxx(Mr. xxx had been in the loop from the start of troubles) was called and after an explanation of the trouble and the work done he returned the aircraft to service at 0900 hrs on 06/20/02.

On 8/3/11 at 1100 H-XXX was dispatched to a fire for bucket work. While going into the heliwell for the second dip, the bucket became snagged on an exposed hose fitting that extended about two inches into the tank. While pulling power to exit the dip, the pilot recognized that the bucket was snagged, reduced power and was able to unsnag the bucket. The pilot did not believe there was mechanical damage to the bucket and continued bucket drops. Because of the short duration of the mission the pilot was able to finish bucket work and land safely. Upon closer inspection, damage to the bucket include: two bent support ribs, ripped suspension straps, and a six inch tear in the top of the bucket wall. The heliwell used is an in ground, fiberglass, 1500 gallon tank. The fitting on the tank included a double female on the external side and a male/female adapter that extended two inches into the tank. The purpose of the fitting was to plumb a pumpkin, allowing the tank to be gravity fed.

We were on our third cycle of the day on the Buzzard fire in the Big Cypress Park, when we decided to abort our bucket mission and return to Helibase. For the past several days, and the previous two cycles of the day, the Air Attack had been running the helicopters and SEATs on the rotor victor...due to the long turn around times this seemed to be working well for everyone, with the Air Attack sequencing all the aircraft together as needed. Before our last cycle, there was an Air Attack transition to a new Air Attack that apparently was not aware that everyone had been working on the same frequency...We had heard that SEATs were coming to the same area again, but were never told when they would be there. Our first drop went just fine, and during the long turn around to the dip, we never heard from Air Attack that SEATs were on station. On our second drop, during which we were talking to a ground contact and flying in smokey conditions while trying to find the drop point, we still hadn’t heard anything, so we went ahead and dropped planning on exiting off our nose and around the smoke as we had done previously. As I sat up after the drop, my copilot pointed out a previously unseen SEAT at our altitude, on our exit path, having just made a drop. I immediately turned 180 degrees away from the area and proceeded back around the column the other way. I was finally able to reach Air Attack, and he said “, Yea, he was talking to the SEAT, and the pilot could see me” and he tried to reach me on the rotor victor but I was talking to the ground, so he just went ahead and sent the SEAT in...We were monitoring the victor the whole time and at no time did we hear the Air Attack try to contact us about the SEAT. At this point, due to the lack of communication and getting no further responses from the Air Attack we decided it would be best to just depart the area and return to the Helibase. We never were able to reach Air Attack again, on the 10 mile trip back to Oasis Helibase to even tell him we that were returning to base.

Idaho City Helibase at the Idaho City Airport {U98} was supporting the Trinity West Fire. Portable fuel containment berms were deployed as requested by the Idaho City RD resource advisor. The portable berm was approximately 15` x 60`, model `Throw N Go` made by Bowhead Environmental & Safety. Type III helicopter returned to helibase from a recon mission before berm was completely set-up. Berm was not staked or weighted down and fuel truck had not yet moved to park on the berm. Due to wind shift the helicopter preferred approach path to landing took it near the berm. Based on size and weight of the berm the crew working with the berm did not anticipate that the berm would be affected by the T-III rotor-wash. Wind from the rotor-wash got under the edge of the berm and rolled/flipped the berm about 30` off the edge of the airstrip into brush. No personnel were in the area and the berm did not contact any equipment, aircraft, or personnel.

The pilot was informed immediately via radio and was unaware that it had fallen off. A ground crew quickly went over to the field and recovered the longline and remote hook shortly after. No damage or injuries occured. The local winds at the time were approximately 20-25 mph. Airspeed was appoximately 40-50 mph. The pilot says he did NOT punch off the line accidently. We believed that the line worked itself loose from the belly hook somehow. We hypothesized that there was enough ''slack'' and/or ''whip'' in the line to make this possible.

Aerial Ignition (Helitorch) After Action ReviewCrazy Horse Fire – MT-FNF-0092 - September 03, 2003 On August 30 & 31, Chrisman’s IMT prepared a tactical assessment of Hemlock Creek drainage and confinement options for the Crazy Horse Fire.  The selected alternative set trigger points to implement an aerial ignition (helitorch) burn-out operation west of Hemlock Lake and at the head of Red Butte Creek (perhaps as soon as September 01).  This tactic was selected as a low risk, low cost means to secure the fire from burning across the ridge into the Crazy Horse or Elk Creek drainages by spotting or surface fire. Helitorch ignition was selected to ignite relatively sparse, heavy fuels when ignited.  The pre-determined trigger point necessitating a burn-out was reached August 31, when the fire passed west of Hemlock Lake. The following discusses the operational and safety components of the action, and captures the critical elements of the After Action Review held on September 2, 2003.PlanningCritical elements of the Aerial Ignition Plan included:·	Preposition resources to implement the aerial ignition plan (Complex Prescribed Fire Burn Boss (RXB1), helitorch, Type III helicopter and module).·	Preposition air resources to use water drops to control flare-ups or spots across the ridge (Type I and II helicopters).·	Discrete communications channel would be assigned to facilitate ‘Air to Ground’ (helitorch platform to helitorch base; Burn-boss air platform, helitorch base, and Division); and helitorch ‘Deck’. ·	The Plan was focused on establishing a fire perimeter in Hemlock drainage that could be held with subsequent helicopter water drops.  Firing was also planned in Red Butte drainage to strengthen the hand ignition done there on August 29 and 30.Implementation – Monday, September 1, 20030700 – Daily operations briefing at ICP, which included notification that the helitorch operation would be conducted this operational period.0715 - Daily operations briefing at helibase, which included notification that the helitorch operation would be conducted this operational period.0830 – Helitorch Manager and Prescribed Fire Burn Boss briefing at helibase to all aerial ignition personnel; assigned discrete radio frequency confirmed/cloned/operational.1015 – Helitorch Manager briefing with helitorch staff, helitorch pilot, IC, OSCs, and Safety Officer at Helitorch Base (DP 8).1145 – Helitorch Manager and Parking Tender brief helitorch pilot.1210 – Operations and Prescribed Fire Burn Boss flies with 16K pilot for orientation and recon of the ignition patterns and sequence of firing. 1225 – Commence burning operation in Hemlock Creek, Operations Colla and Burn Boss Orton in Helicopter NXXXX, Flathead National Forest Lama which is the observation platform.  Helicopter NXXXXX, a Bell 206-L3, is the helitorch platform.Outcomes1)	An Aerial Ignition Plan was prepared and approved by the Forest Aviation Officer. 2)	Operational and safety briefings were conducted by Prescribed Fire Burn Boss and the helibase manager and by Div Z supervisor at H5.3)	During the recon flight, the proposed burn areas in Division’s A and Z  weresurveyed for personnel that could be threatened by the operation. On 5/15/2012 while conducting a helitorch burn, the mixing crew experienced a blown hose. The hose came apart at the Scovill fitting {as seen in Figure 1}. The crew was utilizing the mix transfer system, with a Briggs and Stratton 8hp ohv pump{Figure 2}. This pump while operating at the lowest idle setting has enough pressure to move gel from the mix transfer system through the pump to the discharge side of the pump. Other operations utilize a less powerful pump the Honda GX-160 5.5 hp {Figure 3} which does not move gel to the discharge side of the pump at a low idle. When the pump {Briggs and Stratton} was fired up with no gel being transferred to the helitorch, the pressure release valve never operated which then caused the hose to break away partially from the dry break within 3-5 seconds of starting the pump. Gel did not come in contact with any personnel, very minimal spillage, all PPE was in place and no injuries occurred.

At approximately 2030 hrs on 6/23/08,during initial attack of the Piedra fire {CO-SUA}, one of the six smokejumpers being delivered to the fire was severely injured. Initial reports were a fractured femur with possible tissue/artery damage. Smokejumpers on scene were rendering medical aid and requested a medevac. At this same time, NPS exclusive use helicopter and module {NXXX} were departing this same fire for base and responded to the jump spot. Local EMS helicopter ordered at same time. Once over the jump spot, it was determined by the pilot and helicopter manager that the site was a no-go for the inbound EMS helicopter {Agusta A119}. This was due to the small size and slope of the potential helispot. After weighing the options, NXXX and crew landed and configured aircraft with litter kit. Helicopter then returned to jump spot with HMGB and HECM {both EMTB} to attempt a landing and patient retrieval. Once over the site, the pilot and manager evaluated the situation and due to the significant risk to the patients life, time of day and no ground options for evacuation, it was decided to attempt a landing in this marginal site. The pilot was able to maneuver the aircraft onto the one possible landing site, however the slope exceeded the limit for the NXXX. The pilot brought the aircraft onto the spot, but needed to maintain full power with the back half of the skids off of the ground during the loading of the injured firefighter. Once on the ground, the HMGB and HECM exited, briefed the 5 other jumpers on scene about the loading process and the patient was loaded on aircraft. Helitack crew boarded and the aircraft departed the spot at approximately 2050 hrs. Patient flown directly to Mercy Medical Center in Durango, arrival 2100 hrs. Patient and helitack crew offloaded and NXXX departed for airport, arriving at approximately 2110. As the Helicopter Manager, I feel that the pilot did an exceptional job during this emergency situation. He was able to skillfully pilot the aircraft into a very difficult spot, during low light conditions and successfully retrieve the injured before dark. This injured smokejumper was delivered to the hospital less than one hour after his injury. There were several deviations from policy and SOPs during this operation due to the emergency situation. These were all discussed between pilot and Helicopter Mgr. prior to completing the medevac. These include: - Landing was close to a toe-in situation and required full power to maintain aircraft position during extrication. - Patient transported without full PPE due to injuries. - Aircraft landed at airport past day VFR time. {21:12 vs. 21:06}

On Monday, August 26, 2002 I was ATGS on 58CK, a twin engine Beech Baron, with pilot XXXX XXXXXX. We departed Pueblo at 13:21. Then he said we were not going to make the highway because we were losing altitude too fast. The pilot then said that we were holding altitude at 11,000 feet. There was too much traffic on the highway to land. We were both looking for a road to land on. Just east of 285 was a dirt road running east/west. XXXX said it looked pretty good to him. We made a low pass over the road to look for any problems. It looked doable so XXXX came around to set up on final to land. I called dispatch to let them know our position and that we were landing on the dirt road. XXXX XXXXXX did an outstanding job of landing on the dirt road in an emergency situation in a calm, cool, and professional manner. Once we landed I got out of the plane and called dispatch on my cell phone to let them know the landing had been successful. There were no injuries and no damage to the aircraft. The time when we landed was 14:42.

Soon after take off from RNM the #1 engine began vibrating. The retardant load was jettisoned, the engine was shut down and we radioed back to base that we were having engine problems and were returning.

While flying Air Attack over the Fire, pilot noticed EGT increasing. Richer mixture lowered temp temporarily but then EGT continued to increase. Decision was made to return to airport, on way in EGT hit redline, then began to decrease. Aircraft grounded at ABQ until cause of problem could be determined.

With 728 gallons on board T-XXX departed to the XXX Fire, made two drops, then returned to the Tanker Base for load and return. Aircraft taxied to pit two. Pilot attempted to raise flaps, but could not. Requested to exit the pit to remedy the problem. Fixed the problem and re-entered pit two to reload for the fire at which time retardant exited through the vent on top of the hopper and also the overflow vents. After leaving Ramona air base pilot noticed the #3 engine starting to backfireall temps and pressures normal, reducing power didn't help.  Feather engine, drop 1000 gallons of retardant,and returned to Ramona AP out of service at 1827.

During bucket work on the south side of the Rattlesnake Fire, pilot encountered a black drone at eye level as he was coming out of the dip. This was during the initial attack phase of the fire. The dip site was in the Little Salmon River next to Highway 95.

on august 3, 2011 a state of montana mt205 was dispatched to initial attack a fire 12 miles northeast of bonner, mt. upon arrival at the fire {rainbow bend 961001} the helitack crew attached the bambi bucket to the aircraft and began to fight the fire. the pilot proceeded to the blackfoot river, about ¼ mile north of the fire and commenced bucket operations. following the fourth bucket drop, the aircraft was returning to the river and was in a left turn when the pilot experienced the following: 1. grinding noises coming from the engine/transmission area. 2. excessive vibration. 3. a droop or reduction in rotor rpm. 4. surges in engine rpm. the pilot elected to perform a precautionary landing based on the aircraft behavior. landing options were extremely limited in the area. the pilot initially considered landing on highway 200 but the traffic was too heavy. adjacent to the highway was a small parking area used to access the river. several vehicles were parked in this area with people present. the pilot opted to split the difference between the parking area and the highway and landed on the turn-off area leading into the parking area. this turn-off area resulted in the aircraft landing with 9 degrees of lateral slope from right to left and 4 degrees nose up. the pilot did not jettison the bambi bucket on approach to the landing area, which resulted in his making a near vertical descent to the landing. the bucket was located to the left rear of the left skid, down slope from the aircraft. the bucket cables and bucket position indicated the bucket was placed and not dragged during landing. during the landing the aircraft moved forward about 18 inches from the initial touchdown point of the right rear skid tube. as the pilot placed the aircraft on the slope the aircraft slid about 16 inches down slope as the aircraft came to rest. there was a curved guard rail immediately aft of the aircraft. the final position of the aircraft resulted in a 20 inch separation of the tail skid and the guard rail. evidence suggests that the tail skid and tail rotor were over the guard rail during the landing event. no contact between the aircraft and guard rail occurred. the pilot attempted to perform an emergency engine shut-down following the landing, but failed to move the throttle past the idle cut-off position. the main fuel, and battery switches were placed in the off position. the pilot safely exited the aircraft, retrieved the fire extinguisher. the aircraft produced smoke from the engine/transmission for about 20 minutes after landing.

T-XX had just been loaded and was headed to the Sun Dog Fire on the Flathead N.F. T-XX had a very close encounter upon takeoff from runway 05 at COE with a Cessna 172 that was taking off on runway 01 (the two runways converge at the north end of the field). During this timeframe there were as many as eight aircraft on the airport in various stages of: taxiing, taking-off and/or landing. Two witnesses report that if T-XX had not made evasive manuevers (a left bank at perhaps as little as 100 ft AGL) while fully loaded there would have likely been a collision. The Cessna was also observed making a right bank to avoid the larger aircraft. It appears that the Cessna was not aware of the larger aircraft taking off on runway 05 until the last possible moment. T-XX did announce intentions on unicom. Workers at the airport report that the C-172 did also announce their intentions on unicom. Witnesses report that there may have been as little as fifty feet of horizontal separation between the two aircraft.

On 06/21/2004 aircraft Nxxxx was dispatched for the scheduled afternoon recon. All systems checked OK during the run-up check. We departed at 1552. About 25 minutes into the flight, a slight engine inmissin was observed. At 29 minutes (2 minutes later) a inroughnessin in one of the engines was observed. It was determined that the right magneto on the right engine was suspect. (There are 2 magnetos per engine for safety reasons, the aircraft can safely fly on 1 magneto). The mission was aborted and the aircraft was safely landed back at Flagstaff airport.

After the second fuel cycle during initial attack on the Belli Ranch fire the pilot informed me that during structure protection water drops, he dropped on power lines causing them to arc. I heard the radio traffic prior to this incident and ground forces repeatedly requested the helicopter to drop in this area due to the eminent threat to the structures.

During the ground roll departing runway 29 at KMSO, the flight crew aborted the takeoff due to an apparent compressor stall with the left engine. The non-flying pilot noticed an abnormal indication with the left engine auto-ignition annuniciator and called for the ''''abort''''. At about the same time, the flying pilot noticed the left engine exhaust stack was flaming. After the aborted takeoff, the flightcrew taxied the A/C to a taxiway and ''''ran'''' the left engine up. The auto-ignition light began flicering off and on, the engine was making a ''''popping'''' sound, and a flame was observed coming out of the exhaust stack. The flightcrew then taxied the A/C back to the FBO and conducted one last engine run-up. The non-flying pilot observed the engine instrument gages while the flying pilot watched the left engine. At approximately 1000 lbs. of torque, the auto-ignition light started flickering off and on, the torque gage varied rapidly from 1000 lbs, to 200 lbs. of torque, and flame was again observed from the left engine exhaust stack. The A/C was then shut down and maintenance and management was notified of the problem.

At 1450 on June 29th as aircraft was preparing to launch to a fire, hydraulic fluid was noticed seeping out of the hoist filter hydraulic line during routine inspection. FS Maintenance inspector informed.

After approximately 3 flight hours conducting aerial observation over the Forest, the tachometer stopped indicating RPM. Per FAR 91.205 the aircraft was immediately placed on a heading to the nearest airport and landed without incident. After taxing to the ramp area a magneto check was performed and it was determined the magnetos were operating normally.
On termination on approach to dip site as power was applied #2 engine experienced a soft stall. Aircraft flown out of dip site and engine secured. Aircraft returned to Missoula on one engine.

We were dispatched to a fire in the blue range wilderness section 31 at approximately 1330. We arrived at the fire and were beginning smokejumper operations when we noticed traffic on our TCAS. A lookout also reported a military C130 south of our position. One minute later, the military C130 flew under Jumper aircraft at 200 feet AGL. The fire was located in the Reserve MOA and there is a military training route south of the position we were operating. The reserve MOA is depicted on the sectional and states that military aircraft will be operating from 5000 ft. AGL up to FL180.

This is being filed in response to 05-0595. I am the Assistant Center Manager in the Burns Interagency Communication Center, I wanted to clarify some of the coorination that was happening in the back ground of this incident, that may not have been passed onto the air attack. We had a report of an incident out in the Wagontire area, all of our available aircraft were responding to another incident, so we contacted the shared resources desk at Central Oregon Interagency Dispatch Center. The requests on the aircraft order included 1 Type 3 Helicopter, and 1 SEAT. Confirmation of frequencies were passed onto the center verbally. The order was placed at 1744. At 1752 Central Oregon called to let us know that they would be filling the order, and that they had additional ground resources enroute. At 1819 XXX from Central Oregon called to confirm the command frequency for this fire, it was Dry South. H-XXX contacted Burns Dispatch on the command frequency at 1828, frequencies were again given to the helicopter. At 1848 H-XXX called to let us know that T-XXX may have dropped on another incident but they are in touch with Central Oregon dispatch. At 1902 T-XXX called into Burns Dsipatch letting us know that he had dropped on a fire at 43 19 32 x 120 09 47 which was not the original fire that they were dispatched to, he gave the size up to Burns. When we plotted the fire we were coordinating with COIDC and LIFC as to who''s fire it would be as we all knew that it was a boundary fire. I was on the phone with LIFC to obtain what resources she had responding to this new fire, and what Air-Air Frequency they were operating on. Air-Attack XXX called into BICC to obtain the Air-Air Frequency 125.075. COIDC called to let us know that H-XXX had set down due to wx and gave us an updated lat long of the set down location. We advised Air-Attack of this information. We advised AA-XXX of the Air-Air frequency that the LIFC air resource were operating on as well. There is always a lot of coordination going on in the back ground when we have boundary fires, and the dispatch centers are working with each other to ensure the safety of the fire personnel on the ground and in the air. H-XXX called into Burns Dispatch to let them know that they would be setting down due to an active cell in the area and gave us a location of where they would be setting down.

On 8/20/20, I was enroute to the Walbridge fire from STS. The work area and IP were 14 miles from the airport. I checked in with the ASM and was cleared direct to the work area at 2500. Enroute, during the climb on the east side of HWY 101 I received a TCAS over Fitch Mountain (Healdsburg), acquired the target and maneuvered around it. It was a helicopter westbound at my altitude. Shortly thereafter, I heard someone trying to get clearance into the FTA on 122.92. Although Fitch Mountain and Healdsburg are not in the TFR, they are well within the FTA, and 8 miles from the IP I was given. 

After the drop and during the exit, I received another TCAS. I acquired the target and pointed it out to the ASM. The same helicopter I almost ran into over Healdsburg, was now flying up the retardent line where we were working. 

I was caught by surprise because I wasn’t briefed about any other aircraft in the area. The helicopter wasn’t in the area he was supposed to be and the ASM was also caught by surprise.

Had a second veg. fire in close proximity of Rancho Fire. Rancho Fire assigned frequency is Service Net LaCumbre, dispatcher assigned Davey Fire to Tepesquet Repeater on Forest Net because LaCumbre Forest Net which covered the area has been none operational since early June. Radio communications were directley effected forcing many of the ground and air resources on the Davey Fire to switch to service net LaCumbre causing 2 incidents to operate on the same frequency. At 1514 we broke the Course Fire which was in close proximity of the Rancho Fire and the same scenerio happened.

On August 26th during bucket operations on the Sambrito 2 fire, Hxxx experienced an engine chip light and returned to the Sambrito Helibase and landed without incident. Manager notified maintenance inspector and Hxxx was place out of service. An inspection of the lower chip light plug near the compressor revealed minute metal fragments. The plug was wiped clean and a 30 minute run up was conducted. Approximately 5 minutes into the run up, the engine chip light came on again. The helicopter was shut down and the same plug re-inspected, showing a few more minute metal fragments. Mechanics were called in who inspected the front side of the compressor and discovered that one of the bolts had broken its weld. It was decided to replace the engine.

At 1715, the helicopter returned to the Helibase from a water drop mission to the fire. No issues were reported during the flight. The lead aircraft mechanic did normal post flight check of aircraft systems. At 1730 he reported to me the helicopter was out of service and in need of a gearbox replacement. In a normal check of fluids he discovered metal shavings in the gearbox lubricant. I reported the issue to the local dispatch office and to the Aviation Officer

As the aircraft descended for his tenth load, the pilot reported watching the bucket continue to sink into the water and go out of sight. When he returned to pick up his crew the hook was open and all electrical wiring below the two pin connector was missing. According to the pilot write up, ''''The cargo hook opened without pilot action during sling operations. Bucket jettisoned''''. The hook is part of the ''''Onboard cargo suspension system'''' and requires the hook to be opened in order to attach any load {it does not have the typical spring loaded keeper}. Nothing unusual was observed while deploying the bucket. Maintenace checked the system and could not duplicate the problem.

Tanker was on LCQ taxiway doing a pre-flight run-up prior to take-off enroute to Grand Junction CO to support Whittaker Flats Fire. The tanker was not loaded with retardant. First leg of ferry flight was to Amarillo, TX. The instrument light for ''Fire Warning'' came on. Tanker taxied back into the tanker base and shut down. Mechanics evaluation revealed the Fire Warning Loop (wire) had gone bad.

While snorkeling water, pilot noted torque split.  Pilot released the load by the emergency dump on the fixed tank.  Pilot put #1 engine into manual to bring #1 torque back.  Pilot flew aircraft back to Bruce Meadows Helibase.

Engine #4 fuel pressure dropped from 25 psi to 19 psi and red warning light came on 48in map on take-off.  Tried high boost - went from 30 psi to 19 psi at 48in.  Aborted take-off.  Removed engine-drive fuel pump and replaced it.  Engine operates normally idle through max power and leak check are okay.

At 1500 a citizen called the front desk at King City, LPF, the call was forwarded to the Forest FAO who gave the citizen a telephone number to South Kirk Complex Air Operations director.  At 1515 Air Ops received a phone call from the citizen, stating that inan air tanker had dropped retarded on their trailer and vehicles. The citizen also said that it was a 4 engine aircraft but could not give any further description.  They said that their house is located on Plaskett Ridge, about 5+ miles from the fire.  Air Ops advised the person to wash the retardant from vehicles and building and that a representative would contact them from the incident.

Tanker XXX while on BLM ramp the SEAT pilot attempted to start aircraft twice after cleared. BLM Ramp Manager informed pilot of fuel leaking out of aircraft overflow. The SEAT aircraft could not be started and had to be moved off the BLM ramp to general aviation for maintenence. After inspection the mechanic determined the problem to be a bent pin on the ignitor cannon plug. For temporary correction the pin on the cannon plug was bent back into place to ensure proper connection to the ignitor box. Tanker XXX back in service after successful maintenence check.

On 3-27-2012 at 18:15 T-xx was taxing {while loaded with retardant} on the former FBO ramp just east of the Airtanker Base. While maneuvering on the ground the Right Main landing gear tire broke through a drainage grate and sliced the tire. The Pilot continued forward away from the broken grate, shut down the aircraft and called for the Mechanic. After inspecting the aircraft the Pilot and Mechanic saw no further damage beyond the R/H tire and requested a maintenance break to have the tire replaced. The pilot stated that during taxiing operations the grate was not visible from his vantage point in the cockpit. The Airport Operations Manager was consulted and the load bearing weight was confirmed to be above that of a P2V Neptune at full takeoff weight of 80,000lbs and single wheel. Upon closer inspection the airport found no obvious flaws with the broken grate. The airport has inspected the remaining drainage grated in the ramp and found them to be in good condition.

On July 7, 1999, Helicopter 193 EH was doing bucket work with the relief pilot on the Wah Wah Fire in SW Utah. It was about a 12 min. turn around from the water source to the fire.Attempting a drop, the pilot couldn't release the water and noted that the pigtail had come off. He reported this condition to the helicopter forman(who was also the IC) and who, at that time was at the helispot with two crewmembers.The ship approached the helispot, didn't land but remained in a hover instead with the bucket on the ground. The forman went under the helicopter and was holding on to the bucket, while the one crewmember grabbed the pigtail and plugged it back in. The second crewmember was standing to the side of the ship, caught by suprise by what was going on, because he expected the ship to land so the pigtail could be retaped.The helicopter flew to the fire, released the water and flew back to the helibase, where the pigtail was retaped.

As pilot and manager lifted off airport for recon, ``FADEC FAULT`` light came on, and we sat back down at the airport. Mechanic changed out ECU and went through proper checks and test flight. Aircraft was returned to contract availability by regional maintence inspector.

When pulling pitch for the fifth mission of the day a chip light came on. The mechanic reported ferrous fuzz and several flakes on all plugs. The mechanic cleaned the plugs and flushed the system. The pilot performed an operational check flight for 18 minutes and landed. When the mechanic rechecked the plugs there were more flakes on the plugs. After landing from the last Air Attack flight of the day at 4SD it was noticed upon exiting the Aircraft,it was listing to the left. It was then observed that fluid was leaking from the main left strutt & and down on the left wheel.

He told me later that he has tried every way he can think of to get it to not work but it has been flawless every since.
Upon taxing for take-off the #1 engine would not start.  PIC radioed tanker base to return for mechanical.
Transmission chip light came on at take off. Landed back on the pad and called the Maintenance Inspector. Mechanic pulled the chip detector and found 2 very small metal flex.
Aircraft had an input module chip light illuminate during in-flight operations.  Pilot immediately found a safe place to land the aircraft in an open field.
Intermediate gear box chip light came on, pilot returned to helibase and shut down.

Statement by the Helicopter Manager and Pilot:Helicopter 5738Y was assigned to fly the Isabel fire 20 minutes SW of the Needle Fire. I asked the pilot if he needed the communication information and he said that the Situation Unit Leader made the arrangements to go to the Isabel fire. Prior to departure, the pilot stopped by the Foster Helibase communication trailer to inform them he had been ordered to IR map the fire, Isabel. He was asked if he had the frequencies for the Isabel. He said he had received them from the Needle Air Attack the day before (on 9/14).5738Y departed the Foster Helibase at 1330. In route to the Isabel fire until 1405. 8 miles out, 38Y attempted to contact Salmon Helibase on the given frequency with no result. The pilot tried again a second time again with no avail. 38Y pilot then tried a secondary frequency (not utilized the day before) given to the pilot by the Needle Air Attack. On that frequency he communicated with the Salmon Air Attack and discovered that he had flown into an active air operation.Note: On 9/14 the previous day, 38Y was dispatched to the same fire and the Foster Helibase communications said there were no air operations taking place on the Isabel. Arriving on the fire, there was one type 2 on the ground at the Salmon Helibase.Corrective Actions:Situations needs to go through the proper ordering channel by using the Air Operations Branch Director to place the order. By doing this both Teams will know what aircraft are being used on that incident and can give permission for the flight.Statement by ATGS on 9/15:On 9/15/03 received a request at approx. 10 am for ATGS mission on Isabel fire #637. Aircraft Dispatcher, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, was told at time of request about a new air-to-ground and new victor frequency that he mentioned to me he was unaware of . The requests had not gone thru proper resource order request channels. He spoke with requesting resource about this.During ATGS mission over Isabel at approx. 1400 I spotted a jet ranger in the fire airspace over a ridge where Lead 69 and air tankers were working. I immediately notified Lead 69 and inquired at Salmon helibase if they knew about this helicopter. They did not. Soon after that 38Y identified himself saying his mission was mapping. I told him that would not be possible at this time as we had T-62 about 2 minutes out and another tanker soon after. I moved him east of the fire camp area or said he could set down at Salmon helibase. I told him to stay below 7,000’. Lead 69 then requested he move north and east of the fire camp as directly east would be “the down and out” for the tankers how he was setting that up. 38Y stated he had tried to contact the fire using yesterdays frequencies and when no one answered, assumed on one was over the fire so came on into airspace. I gave him the correct (new) frequencies and both Lead 69 and myself discussed the situation that had occurred with him over the radio as we were departing fire, mission complete.Statement by Aircraft Dispatcher:At 0946 received a radio call from Air Ops requesting our Air Attack 634CT to come to Isabel Fire to access need for Air Tankers on incident. At that time he gave me new victor Freq. and new Air Ground Freq. I asked him where they got the new Freqs, since I had no request from ICP for new Freqs for the incident., he told me he got Freqs from the  communication unit leader. I then called the Communication Unit Leader and asked him where he got the Freqs and he told me he called NIC and got them from them. I then told him since I had the Aircraft Orders for the Incident and that the orders needed to come through me at CWICC so I could track them in Ross and coordinate those freqs with our responding  aircraft.  I knew nothing about the Isabel Fire contacting the Needle Fire and requesting the use of a helicopter, which the order should have came through me at CWICC since I have all aircraft for both  Incidents and they need to be tracked in Ross for proper payment and tracking of aircraft use. If the proper procedures would of been followed the Freqs would have been passed on to N38Y before he was dispatched to the Isabel Fire.  I knew nothing about the near miss over incident until later when XXXXXXXX -Helibase Manager for the Needle Fire called me and told me about what happened.Statement by XXXXXXXXX, ASGS Isabel:Helicopter 38Y departed the Needles fire to map the Isabel fire without the proper radio frequencies. 38Y failed to establish contact at 12NM from the Isabel fire and did not hold at 7NM when contact was not established with Air Attack or the Helibase.The first contact with 38Y was with Air Attack as 38Y flew into the fire area. The other aircraft over the incident were Lead 69, tankers 62 and 66 and SEAT 185. The presence of 38Y unannounced over the fire during tanker operations created an unsafe working environment and could have resulted in an aircraft mishap. Wenatchee Air Attack and Lead 69 did a very good job of keeping control of the airspace and keeping 38Y in a safe working area away from the tanker operation.

While flying an air attack mission inside an established TFR we encountered a single engine low wing aircraft within 1/2 mile of us and a helicopter working the fire. The unauthorized aircraft was at our altitude, 1500 ft. I asked the Flagler Helibase to notify FAA - they reported back that FAA was tracking the aircraft and would contact the pilot when the aircraft landed. Was later informed that the FAA in Daytona Beach decided to not pursue any action against the pilot since he was on a filed IFR flight plan and inwas a little lost.in At least one other non-fire aircraft was seen in the same area the same day, and aircraft were seen taking off and landing at OMN which the FAA said was fine even within the TFR as long as they were under IFR flight plans, and even without our concurrence or knowledge.

While flying from Hope, Arkansas to Brookhaven, Mississippi the pilot observed the #2 hydraulic warning light. The pilot landed at the closest airport which was Bastrop, Louisiana. The mechanic found that the retaining clip in the #2 hydaulic pump had failed allowing the pump shaft to work its way out of the pump causing loss of hydraulic boost to the collective.

Aircraft was en route from MAF to the Big Trickle Ranch Fire with ATGS as relief for the ATGS currently working the fire. Radio contact was made twice with the Midland TFS dispatcher who informed us we were AFF positive. When it was attempted to contact other Dispatch locations it was discovered that both Technisonic TDFM-136 FM radios were malfunctioning: they did not transmit {or receive, it seemed}. It was quickly seen that the transmit frequencies displayed on each channel were not those that were previously programed. All frequencies for this Incident {West Texas Initial Attack 2011} had been verified by the pilot and ATGS the day before. The radios would not accept reprogramming of the frequencies: and it looked like the transmit frequency was defaulting to the receive frequency when reprogramming was attempted.

While conducting water bucket operations I was climbing up the Mule Creek drainage from the Muriel Dip site with a 3000 lb bucket of water in 1/4 to 1/2 mile visibility when I met Air Attack in helicopter flying down the Mule Creek drainage. I took evasive action and moved to the opposite side of the drainage to resolve the airspace conflict. I never heard Air Attack announced his intentions to do a low level recon. It was my understanding that it was an Air Attack, not a HELCO. Per USFS policy and our pilot national safety briefing, we are to follow the Fire Traffic Area airspace layout which establishes Air Attack 1000'' above fire suppression aircraft. Air Attacks low level flying lead to poor radio communication with the other helicopters on the fire resulting in a loss of situational awareness by air attack. This was evident by the number of radio calls air attack made to reestablish where his helicopters were working after his low level flights. The Mule Creek drainage is very narrow. Climbing up hill, in low visibility, with a 1 1/2 ton load and taking action to avoid air attack is unsettling at best. I expect a higher degree of professionalism and flight discipline from the air attack platform.

A HMGB from an exclusive ship parked on an adjacent pad noticed some flame out of the left exhaust during the first start up in the morning. He walked from his pad toward the ship approaching from the rear of the ship, out of view of the pilot, while the rotors were turning. The marshaller was trying to get his attention to stop as he approached the ship. The mechanic was also out by the ship monitoring the start up. I finally got the attention of the person approaching the ship as he made his way towards the front of the ship, within the safety circle and had him progress over to the marshaller. We then went over to notify the pilot, approaching from the front of the ship.

The ship held hover while dip site helitack personnel successfully released the hose from the bucket.  Operations continued as normal.

This incident occurred on a proficiency jump mission. The smokejumpers were using a jump spot used frequently for refresher jumps and training. After wind drift was determined with an initial and check set of streamers the 1st stick received a pre-jump briefing and were placed in the door after turning on base for final. Shortly after the command, “On Final, 1500” was given, the co-pilot recognized the aircraft was not at jump altitude and told the pilot to “standby we are not on our altitude. The spotter did not hear this communication as his head was out of the airplane to line up the spot. As the spotter brought his head back in, the slap was given after the command to “Get Ready” and 2 jumpers exited the aircraft. While slapping the 1st jumper the spotter heard “standby” not knowing why it was given. The pilot informed the spotter that they were not at jump altitude. It was estimated that the jumpers went out at 1300’ AGL. Once the correct altitude was determined, jump ops continued.

At approximately 1045 the Wiens HB TOLC overheard radio traffic between helicopter 02W and North Hayman Air Attack (1AB) on 123.725.  Air attack advised TOLC 02W was inbount to Wiens helibase.  At 1050 the base TOLC was in communication with Air Attack as well as helicopter 790, 661, and 48Y who were inbound for fuel.  At 1056 the TOLC confirmed that 790 had landed and was refueling when he noticed 02W hovering over the dirt road at the north end of the deck.  The TOLC tried repeatedly to raise 02W on air to ground (169.200) with no response as well as on victor frequency (123.725 with no response.  The deck manager provided direction on which pad 02W should land on as well as a marshaller.  Just prior to this landing the same pad had been designated for helicopter 12WW who was just departing the Hayman North incident.  12WW had to be diverted to a pad at the south end of the helibase.  At approximately 1120 the pilot of 02W entered the communications trailer asking about a takeoff and landing frequency.  He told TOLC and ABRO that he had been given the frequency of 169.100 as our air to ground.  He was advised of our correct air to ground/TOLC frequency of 169.200 and departed safely.  At 1200 the pilot phoned the Wiens helibase to further clarify frequencies.  He had been give an IAP at Lake George Helibase and assumed the frequencies were the same.  I explained that not only did we have different frequencies but the Hayman North and Hayman South were two distinctly different fires with different teams.  I also spoke with the HCWN and faxed him our 220 and airspace coordination guidelines.

On July 13th, 2019 GBCC called right around 2000 to advise that they had a VLAT headed for an RON in Pocatello that they wanted to jettison in Northern Utah. They were originally headed to the 123 fire, but due to the lack of a Lead plane, ended up needing to jettison a load of retardant. Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}1 relayed the lat/long for the South Ridge Promontory Point jettison site to the pilot via radio on the National Flight Follow NFF frequency. The lat/long given was 40 16.9833 x 112 28.4000, which was obtained via a paper sign that hangs behind the aircraft desk. Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}1 went off shift, and briefed Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2. At 2052, as the T-XYZ appeared over the Great Salt Lake in AFF, he came up on NFF and said that he had passed the jettison point, mentioned Tooele Army Depot, and Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2 confirmed the coordinates we had with him. He confirmed the coordinates, said that it was behind him and he needed to do a 180 to get there and asked if that is what we’d like him to do. We looked at AFF, and grabbed a GPS point from the program, which was at 41 17.1546 x 112 33.304, was ½ mile directly west of Promontory Point. As he was flying at 357 knots, and the position data was at least 2 minutes old, were unsure of his actual position but knew it would be north of there. We instructed him to turn around and fly back to the confirmed coordinates to jettison the load. He agreed. At around 2110, Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2 – told me that she thought the two jettison sites signs were mixed up, and that T-XYZ was actually headed to a jettison site called Rock Creek. She showed me AFF which put T-XYZ near the Tooele Army Depot, and showed me a map in CAD of the plotted coordinates of what was at 40 16.9833 x 112 28.4000. It was a chunk of BLM land east of the toe of the slope of the Onaqui Mountains, south of Highway 199, and West of the Tooele Army Depot. After looking at the spot, I was fairly certain that was not a jettison spot as I thought all three of ours were on Promontory Point, however I did not think we had enough time to get the pilot back up to the correct area to jettison before pumpkin time which was in about 12 or 13 minutes. I figured it was safer to have him jettison in the light in an inappropriate area, so that he could still see and avoid things that needed to be avoided, than to have him jettison in the dark and potentially endanger the lives of all pilots on board the aircraft, and possibly people on the ground. After he had moved away from the coordinates, the pilot confirmed that he had dropped his retardant at the given coordinates. We confirmed with the tanker base that the pilot had dropped 9,395 gallons of retardant from an altitude of 500 ft AGL.

On the evening of 06/30/17, at around 2000, during his post flight inspection, our pilot noticed a small amount of oil under the belly of the aircraft. Another cyclic servo was ordered and installed on 07/01/17. During the post test flight the mechanic diagnosed a leaking hydraulic accumulator, and replaced the ``o`` ring fixing the problem. A final maintenance test flight was performed, and the aircraft was found to be airworthy. The log entries were sent to the region 3 maintenance inspector who accepted the maintenance and returned the aircraft to contract availability.

On the morning of 6/30 helicopter NXXXX was enroute for a routine reconnaissance of Saguaro NP. During recon a crewmember spotted smoke in the Devils Bathtub area. While sizing up the smoke it was realized by the pilot and crew that onboard communications and FM transmissions had been compromised. At this point the pilot diagnosed the issue as a tripped breaker in the avionics. After resetting the breaker and reestablishing communications the breaker popped a second time. Due to the simplicity of the airspace at the time the pilot chose not to reset the breaker a second time, and promptly returned to helibase to further diagnose the problem. Flight time from the smoke back to helibase was less than four minutes. Upon landing the HMBG{t} quickly made a phone call to Tucson dispatch to explain the brief period of lost communications. During this period of time the pilot and manager understood that the ship was still positive on AFF.

On 8/31/2018 at approximately 1700 helicopter was dispatched to two new starts in the Uncompahgre Forest south of Grand Junction Colorado. Weather for the afternoon was high temps in the upper 80s and scattered thunderstorms. After initial size-up the plan was to land and insert 4 Helitack to take action on both single tree fires. An unimproved landing zone was selected by the pilot and manager. As the ship descended the pilot leaned out the bubble to determine if the slope was too great for landing. At about 5 feet above the tree level the pilot requested rear right crewmember to open the door and check for rotor clearance. After checking and clearing the main rotor he looked back to check the tail. The tail rotor was already in contact with the upper 1/3 branches of a large juniper tree. Crewmember immediately reported ``your tail is in the branches`` at which time the pilot aborted the landing and gained altitude to access for vibrations and airworthiness. The ship departed the location for an emergency landing site about 2 miles away. The ship landed safely and shut down, upon inspection both tail rotor blades had received damage to the outer area {side} of the blades and not to the leading edge but the damages were beyond tolerance and the ship was out of service. The tail rotor blades and hub were replaced the next day. After a maintenance flight and approval from the Aviation Maintenance Inspector the ship was returned to service.

At 1345 local while working the Arlene fire in southern AZ, we received a low hydraulic pressure annunciator followed by a master caution warning. As my crew and I went through the emergency procedures checklist the annunciator extinguished and re-illuminated 2-3 times, eventually coming on steady after a few minutes. A relief aircraft was ordered and we began preparing to return to Libby ATB. The return flight and landing was uneventful with the landing gear extending normally. Upon exiting the aircraft I noticed hydraulic fluid dripping from the left flap. Further inspection showed hydraulic fluid under the left wing and inside the left wheel well. After removing the servicing cover I noted the hydraulic fluid level was below the add mark with approximately ½ inch of fluid remaining.

We departed from Missoula for a mission on the Wood Lake Fire.  After flying a fuel cycle we went to an established helibase in Augusta to get fuel from a sister helicopter from the same helicopter company.  This helicopter is a T3, the fuel truck used to fill the helicopter is for a T2.  The re-fueling hose for the T2 is larger than the one used for the T3.  The company has an adapter that slides over the nozzle, which they used in this case.  The individual fueling the helicopter was carded for T2's but not T3's.  After fueling and while pulling the nozzle out of the fueling port, the adapter slid off and fell into the helicopters fuel tank.  It was noticed and reported immediately to the manager.  The helicopter was non-operational and required the mechanic to drive from Missoula to fix the problem.

Helicopter-XXX was providing water delivery support to the fire with a bucket and 150` longline. The fire was staffed with three firefighters & the IC was directing the helicopter bucket drops. 6 Helitack personnel were staffing the Helispot, approximately 4 miles Southwest of the fire, in support of the water delivery mission. The helicopter had established a dipsite approximately 2 miles Southwest of the fire in the New River and had used this dipsite during the previous fuel cycle, delivering 6 bucket drops to the fire. At 1810 hours, Air Attack notified the HMGB on Air to Ground that the helicopter`s bucket struck a snag & the helicopter would be flying back to the helispot to assess the damage. The helicopter had already completed 6 drops from this dipsite during the current fuel cycle. Upon arrival at the helispot, the HMGB assessed the damage to the bucket, conferred with the pilot and both agreed that the damage could not be fixed at the helispot. Upon arrival at base, the mechanic determined that the bucket would have to be sent in for repair.

On 05/13/2006 at 0830 an Air Tanker was ordered to a fire. 08:30 Air Flight crew was notified and Mix Master was notified and in route. 09:00 loading operations were in progress when the ATBM (trainee) contacted the ATBM on site and informed him that there was a problem with the retardant loading operation. While loading the aircraft the Mix Master noted a problem with the refractor readings on the specific gravity of the retardant mix being loaded onto the Air Tanker. After several attempts by the ATBM (T), ATBM and the Mix Master determine the retardant specific gravity. It became apparent that the load of retardant was not mixed with water and was being loaded with HVR concentrate retardant. Loading procedures were terminated at approximately 22096.22 lbs of retardant (2400gls). Air Tanker was spooled up and waiting for confirmation on launch. ATBM discussed the situation with the Air Tanker Pilot and informed him that the load was straight HVR concentrate. After confirming with the Forest Liaison Officer, ATBM (T), and Mix Master the ATBM determined that the Air Tanker return to the pit, shut down and off load the HVR concentrate. The ATBM then initiated a SAFE COM and began notifying the proper personnel. Personnel contacted: Forest Aviation Officer, Vender COR, Vender Structural Engineer, National Forest Aviation Liaison, and Aircraft Maintenance Specialist for Region, Region Safety Officer and Retardant Specialist. Safety briefings were conducted on base and documented.

We were on a detection flight and received a call from XXX Dispatch to proceed to a smoke report in the north Bridger Mountains. It was described to us as being above the old Morgan Cemetery, a place known to both myself and the observer. This info indicated that the smoke had been called in by an observer on the ground. We were also given a Lat/Long, which was reported to have come from a civilian aircraft. We proceeded to the location and quickly spotted the smoke, flew to it and began to orbit at approximately 1000 ft agl for a size-up. After a few orbits around the fire, we suddenly saw a glider at our altitude also orbiting the fire at very close range to our aircraft. I broke off to avoid the risk of a mid-air collision, flew some distance away and called XXXX tower to ask if they were in contact with the glider. They stated that they had been and in fact the glider was the entity that had called in the Lat/Long coordinates but they were no longer in radio comm with the glider at that time. With no way to contact the glider we departed the incident. After landing, I determined who was flying the glider and called that individual to talk about the dangerous situation that had developed. He stated that after calling in the smoke and flying away, he had returned to it to check it out. I thanked him for calling in the smoke with a Lat/Long position but suggested that in the future he should then remain clear as some agency aircraft were probably going to show up in short order.

At approximately 1400 on Sunday afternoon I received a report of a guy preparing to launch a drone near Lucia CA off of HW1. I immediately called air attach and informed him that there was a report of a drone preparing to launch near Lucia about 15 miles to the SE of his location and asked him to confirm that it was indeed outside of the fire TFR. The air attack confirmed that the location was 5 miles outside of the TFR. Meanwhile the TFLD that reported the drone turned around and went back to the drone location to talk to the pilot. By the time the TFLD reached the drone location the operator had packed up and left the area. Presumably because he saw the agency vehicle slow down and turn around. I then informed the incident air attack that the drone operator had left the are and was nowhere to be found. About 45 minutes later I received another call about a second drone sighting. This time it was flying inside of the TFR {and in a Condor sanctuary no fly zone} and a quarter mile from where our helicopters were dipping from about an hour before the sighting. I again reported the sighting to airattack who was working with several aircraft up drainage {2.5 miles N @ 4,000 ground elevation} from the drone location {sea level}. I instructed the STLD who reported the drone to solicit the help of the park rangers and confront the drone operator. They were successful in convincing the pilot to land the drone and to stop flying the drone near the fire TFR. Although I asked the STLD to collect any information about the drone and the pilot that he could he was unsuccessful as the pilot made a speedy getaway during a very high road traffic area and time. We immediately made contact with airattack and informed him that the drone had landed and was no longer a factor. An AAR was done the following day using the NWCG UAS Reporting Protocol matrix. Everything was done in the proper sequence and in a timely matter. We used that opportunity as a learning moment for everyone on the decision and stressed the importance to immediately report any drone airings up the chain of command and to the controlling airattack or aircraft.

At approximately 1345 aircraft departed the North Fork Fire for a retardant dropping mission on the French Fire. After about 1.5 hours into the fuel cycle the pilots noticed the engine oil pressure in the {#}1 engine dropped. According to the pilots, this is what took place: ``As we were descending for our 5th drop of retardant we noticed our number 1 engine oil pressure drop to the bottom of the precautionary range {40 psi}. This immediately grabbed our attention and we continued with the drop as we had power out, were lined up, and needed to shed the weight anyway if we have a legitimate engine oil system failure. We made our run-out downhill and loaded the engine to see if an increased power requirement would bring the pressure back up to the normal range. It did not but rather stayed in the precautionary range so we notified air attack we were returning to the helibase with an engine oil pressure in the precautionary range as we came off the drop. We emphasized that we weren’t in a dire situation and he kindly asked us to notify him when we make it safely back. Enroute to the helibase the oil pressure continued to decay and we shut down the {#}1 engine at the top of the ridge above helibase,{approximately 2 miles out} as the oil pressure started to drop below the precautionary range. Right after we cleared the tank for landing, we contacted air-attack and told him landing assured and made an uneventful, single-engine landing at approximately 1548. Subsequent inspection determined the number 1 engine oil pressure relief valve failed thus causing the decay in pressure. One of the final steps in in the Before Landing Checks is disarming the tank which causes the doors to open and any residual water or retardant to come out. This is {and was in this instance} done over an unpopulated area. Approximately 20 gal of residual retardant came out due to not having had the opportunity for a rinse load as the final turn of the cycle”.

The relief mechanic was performing a post shut-down inspection of the main rotor system. during this inspection, the mechanic noted play in both red and white stabilizer bar damper links. while the amount of play noted was consistent with normal wear of the rod end bearings and would not typically cause alarm, the mechanic remembered that the primary mechanic had stated at the last relief that he planned to replace the links, so the mechanic inspected the links more closely. it was at this more detailed inspection that the mechanic noted that the play was actually caused by premature wear of the rivets which secure the rod ends to the link tubes. at this time the mechanic made the decision to ground the aircraft based upon the fact that the rivets had worn to an unaccepable level in just over 30 hours. while waiting for the replacement parts to arrive with the fuel truck and maintenance trailer, the mechanic performed a detailed in spection of the subject parts and noted that the links were assembled with incorrect hardware and no structural adhesive, as directed in the bell helicopter standard practices manual {bht-all-spm}. the rivets installed were a 2024 alloy with a dd temper. this rivet has a shear loading capacity of 41000 psi. the required rivet is made from monel and has a shear strength of 49000 psi. it is noted that the identifying marks on a dd rivet are two raised dashes while the monel is identified by two raised dots. the parts had been purchased from XXXXXX XXXX, inc.

During set up for the OGE hover prior to rappel operations the front seat ride along passenger noticed a master caution light come on. We completed rappel sequence and cargo let down operations and had an AAR on the events that unfolded. We talked about the intermittent “caution panel” caution light that is accompanied by the Master Caution light on the front dash. This light cannot be extinguished while illuminated because it means that the Caution Panel is INOP. The helicopter mechanic believes the light comes on due to a faulty relay. This led to a discussion that the Intermittent Caution Panel could cause a concern while in rappel operations. If the sequence was different and the light happened to come on during rappel operations it becomes an expedite and could mask other possible issues if the pilot is concentrating on flying the helicopter

During bucket operations on the XXX fire the long line became wrapped over the rear right skid of the helicopter. Hotshots Perspective: Hotshots were working helo in division alpha doing bucket drops. Helo returned from dip to hotshots and made a drop. After the drop hotshots returned to work and did not see anything wrong during the drop. They noted that the pilot had been doing good work, but the winds were a little squirrely with an upslope component. The also stated that Helo was droping 50 to 100 feet above canopy. After drop helo returned to alpha dip. Div-A perspective: Div-A was at a cabin adjacent to alpha dip with an engine. Helo was going back and forth between alpha dip and dropping water in XXX canyon. There was a middle ridge in between the dip and where the drops were taking place. Distance from dip to middle ridge was described as around mile. Div-A noted that he saw the helo near the middle ridge and the bucket appeared to be flying erratically but was pretty far away and he was looking through some canopy when he made the observation. The Helo then arrived at the dip and the bucket started to come down through canopy. As the bucket came down an Engine crewmember alerted division that the long line was over the skid. Div-A contacted helo and alerted pilot as bucket was entering water. Pilot asked if it was over the front or back and was told back. Pilot then lifted and appeared to be releasing water as he lifted. Pilot then returned to Helitack to get fixed. Engine Perspective: Engine was at alpha dip with Div- A, Engine noticed Helo flying to dip making S-turns on the approach. As helo came to the dip and started to lower bucket towards water they saw the long line was over the skid and notified division. Pilot Comment - I was supporting XXX Hot Shots with a 240gal bambi bucket on the XXX Fire 06/26/2019 at approximately 1200 local time. At drop {{{#}}}11 my ground contact asked for a trail drop about 400 feet higher on the ridge above the previous drops. I made the drop and climbed over the ridge and started my descent to the dip site. The dip site was relatively close and at a lower altitude. I flew some S-turns to slow my forward progress to allow more time to descend. I filled the bambi bucket at the dip site and as I picked the bucket up the helicopter gently rolled a little to the right. I lowered the bucket back into the pond and slowly picked it up again and the same gentle roll repeated. I released the water because I suspected the long line was hung up somewhere on the helicopter’s landing gear. The dip site manager confirmed my suspicion. I released the water and flew back to Heli-Spot 3. Upon landing it was discovered the long line was over the portion of the skid tube behind the aft cross tube. My helitack crew fixed the problem and I returned to supporting the hot shots. The thunderstorms that air attack briefed us on were starting to form and winds were moderate but manageable. During my S-Turn descent my air speed was between 30-40kts to minimize forward progress to allow more time to descend to the dip site. My turns where never more then 20 degrees each direction and control movements during the drops where never excessive. Manager comments – Helicopter launched from helibase at 10:40am for bucket work. Helicopter was configured for bucket operations at H-3. Longline and bucket configuration was correctly completed and all checks were made without incident. Helitack personnel were at H-3 when Div informed Helicopter XXX of longline issue. As soon as Div reported the issue the pilot released the water and flew to the helispot. The helicopter was landing at the helispot when we took some photos of the longline over the skid. The manager spoke with the pilot while HECM’s fixed the longline as well as inspected it for any damage. No damage was identified on the longline, bucket or aircraft. The pilot and manager discussed any concerns with the weather, dip site and bucket operations overall. Pilot stated everything was going well but the winds were “squirrely” do to outflow winds from a system building nearby. He and I felt comfortable returning back to bucket operations to finish the 20 minutes left on the fuel cycle, which was completed without incident. When we returned to helibase we called an AMI about any concerns he may have. AMI had no concerns. We re-inspected the longline and bucket, everything looked as it should and was in good working order. XXX had completed 11 drops without incident prior to longline over skid incident. Air Attack had reported feeling outflow winds shortly before the incident with the longline. The distance between the dipsite and dropping area was approximately 1 mile with a ridge line between the two.

At approximately 1745 Helicopter Helicopter1 entered a dipsite on the Rogue River after Helicopter2 had departed. The lighting was flat, and as Helicopter1’s FAST bucket entered the water, it rolled over into itself and the wires became tangled with the power head. The pilot re-positioned the bucket on a gravel bar adjacent to the dipsite to see if the problem could correct itself. The re-positioning caused one of the tangled wires to push the retaining band and gasket off, which holds the bucket material around the gate valve. The pilot notified Air Attack of the issue and was directed back to base along with the other helicopter as sunset was approaching. There was minor damage to the bucket consisting of two cables that had become kinked, and the missing band and gasket. No other damage was found.
