Helicopter XXX responded to a call for initial attack resources to the Travertine fire in Death Valley National Park. The Type 2 ship dropped of its helitack crew on the fire and intiated bucket drops on the fire. The fuel truck for XXX was routed to the fire by an initial route through Trona, CA. It was then turned around and rerouted to the scene via a longer route. XXX ceased initial attack operation due to low fuel and landed near the NW flank of the fire. After an extended down time and encroachement into the vicinity by the head of the fire, the pilot was forced to relocate the ship. Due to low fuel the ship was not able to fly less than 2 miles to the nearby Furnace Creek Airport. It landed in a small parking lot of the Furnace Creek Inn adjacent to Hwy 190. Fortunately the Inn was closed for the season and no vehicles were present in the lot. The low fuel condition of the aircraft forced the pilot to land in a compromised landing zone that was not designated for this purpose. The Furnace Creek Airport is in close proximity to the Furnace Creek Inn. The XXX fuel truck arrived at the end of the operational period rendering XXX inoperable for most of the operational period on the fire. Additional acres were lost to the fire as a result. HWY 190 was closed as the fire burned westward on the north side of the highway. The fire was contained by NPS/BLM engine crews along the road.

7/17/2014 Two TFR’s were in place over their respective fires. The fires rapidly grew the night of 7/17-18 growing 20 miles beyond the boundaries of the TFRs. Four fires effectively merged into one which became a complex fire. 7/18/2014 In the morning, Air Attack noticed that a private company had taken independent action outside the TFRs on the fires southern perimeter with ground forces {crew, dozer,etc}. They had two helicopters supporting the private independent action outside the TFR. The helicopters did not have communications with fire team ATGS. The ATGS contacted Air Attack and it was decided that the ATGS would attempt contact with the private helicopters while Air Attack continued duties elsewhere on the now very large incident. The ATGS contacted them at the local airport and made arrangement for the forces to continue, as not being a factor to government supervised aircraft, as long as they were in communication on ATGS assigned Air to Air and Air to Ground Frequencies. Later that day at 1830, another TFR was put into place that covered the current fire and expected growth. The new TFR extended over the area the private crews were working. The private ships continued operation while the ATGS’s kept other incident aircraft separated from them. 7/19/2014 Private fire forces continued to take action as the day before, but now the TFR was in place that covered their operations where two private helicopters were working. Fire forces engaged the fire, specifically trying to protect a structure. The complex fire forces on the ground tried contacting the helicopters. The ATGS tried also. Neither helicopter communicated with the ATGS to ask permission to enter the TFR, nor did they communicate when asked to do so. All complex fire aviation forces were withdrawn from the area. Ground forces did not feel safe without agency air support so they also disengaged. The manager of the private company was contacted later in the day by the complex IC who explained the gravity of TFR violation and the effect of their forces on the planned action of the complex forces. The manager said his forces would comply with the communications, but would continue to take independent action with all his forces. 7/20/2014 Private forces continued action. The private company requested a change in the TFR so they could dry cherry orchards with predicted rain on 7/22 and fight fire. Private aircraft did comply with radio communications. Complex aviation assets were separated from their forces. 7/21/2014 Private forces continued action. Private aircraft did comply with radio communications. Complex aviation assets were separated from their forces. The fire behavior was such by then that a change in the TFR was justified. The TFR was changed effective about 1800 and to continue daily. This TFR excluded the orchards and the independent fire action area.

Crew was alerted for a MAFFS mission to the Million Fire from Colorado Springs at 1500 local(mdt), after sitting on standby for the previous 3 days without flying.  This was the first fire mission for this crew, this season.  It was discovered in the pits, prior to launch, that the MAFFS unit dispensing tubes would not relock in the exended position once brought into the aircraft.  So the pilot decided to leave the tubes out and locked and fly to the fire unpressurized.  On the previous flight (deployment from Charlotte, NC to Co. Springs)an equipment malfunction code affecting the radar was discovered by the crew, which resolved itself well prior to reaching Co. Springs and showed no further indication of degradation.  Just prior to take off on the incident flight, the crew again had the equipment malfunctions code, and took off expecting to code to clear.  After takeoff the pilot climbed to 10,000 msg and visually cleared terrain crossing the first ridge southwest of Co. Springs and on across the valley that provided terrain clearance.  During this time the navigator was having increasing difficulty using the radar for terrain clearance.  The visibility was deteriorating but still well above VFR.  As the crew worked to clear the radar problem and plot position using GPS, the pilot was skirting high terrain on the left with lower terrain on the right.  The pilot attempted to cut across the end of a ridge extending from the terrain on the left to the valley on the right.  As the aircraft passed the extension of the ridge on the right he realized that he may be able to cross the saddle and went to maximum power and flaps 50%.  The flight engineer closed the engine bleed valves for maximum power.  After a few seconds the crew realized for sure they would not clear the saddle on the right and the pilot turned left up the canyon towards the last remaining option, a shallow saddle between two peeks.  The pilot directed emergency drop of the retardant load and flaps to 60%.  The copilot and loadmasters accomplished the drop and the copilot positioned the flaps to 60%.  As the load went out, the aircraft climbed over the saddle and out over low terrain.  The crew returned to Co.Springs, uneventfully, and shut down for the day.

At about 1730 hours, July 14, 2003, Coronado Initial Attack Dispatch called me to see if I was available to fly to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation to work on an initial attack fire, the Popcorn Incident.  I replied that I was, and acquired all the necessary information, including resource order numbers, frequencies, air and ground contacts, etc.  My pilot and I departed Tucson International Airport (TIA) at 1816, under partly cloudy, but threatening skies.  Airport weather indicated moderate to severe thunderstorms to the northeast and southeast of the airport. As we cleared the terrain to the north of Tucson, we began to receive radio traffic from the SCA aerial observer, P3, who was flying over the fire, and I called San Carlos Dispatch to let them know I was inbound to the Popcorn Fire, and approximate ete to the fire.  San Carlos Dispatch told me that P3 was over the fire and that he seemed to be having trouble transmitting over the assigned VHF frequency, 127.975. Between 1824 and 1857 hours, as we approached the fire area, P3 was attempting to talk to heavy air tanker, T55, SEATS 411 and 459, both flying out of the SEAT Base at Whiteriver, and me, on VHF 127.975.  As I got closer, it became apparent that the pilot who was flying P3 was in communication with T55, who was on scene, and that from the target description being given to T55, the P3 pilot intended to drop T55`s retardant load on the fire.  At 1850, T55 did drop his load on the fire.  When I got to within 12 nautical miles to the south of the fire, I called P3 on the victor frequency to seek permission to proceed to the fire.  As he had his hands full, he told me to stay where I was until he told me otherwise.  We went into an orbit around the east side of San Carlos Reservoir, and I noted that the air was extremely filled with smoke at that point.  We were orbiting at 9,500' and as we listened to the radio traffic, the overload on the observer was apparent.  At about that time, first he mentioned that two unidentified helicopters had gone through his airspace from the direction of Whiteriver, and a little later, he said that a news media helicopter had entered the airspace unannounced and without permission.By then, the two SEATS who had been working the fire were back in the airspace, and it didn't seem that either the pilot or observer of P3 had a firm grasp on the situation.  At this point, my pilot, whom I was flying with for the first time on 07/14/03, told me he felt very uncomfortable entering or proceeding into the airspace under the present escalating circumstances, so I called P3 and then San Carlos Dispatch and told them I thought they had an unsafe situation on their hands and that we were returning to Tucson.  They told me that was my option, so at 1857 hours, we returned to Tucson, where we landed at 1922.

While performing a reconnaissance/GPS mapping flight for a fast moving DNR fire, helicopter pilot noticed an airplane making a low pass in front of the helicopter. Pilot responded by making a sharp right turn, discontinuing the mission and returned to the helispot. Radio contact was made with the lead plane assigned to the fire and it was determined that the lead plane made the low pass. The leadplane pilot acknowledged that he did not warn the helicopter of the intended low pass and apologized. Leadplane pilot indicated his TCAS alerted him to the presence of the helicopter causing him to take evasive manouvers. Helicopter pilot did not feel there had been a danger of collision, but his comfort level was exceeded. He later stated that in his opinion in view of intense air activity, the need for the recon/GPS mapping mission was questionable and that those missions should have been carried out by ground personnel or at a later time. At the time of the incident, Air Attack was away for refueling and 5 air tankers, 2 leadplanes, a SEAT, a PBY and 2 helicopters were assigned to the fire.

Helibase Mgmt Comments: While working on the incident it was determined that multiple helibases would work better, one for each type of helicopter. There were new areas designated for the two new helibases. I was sent to help develop Blue helibase with several folks. We left the main helibase, Milan, with the impression that we were to get the helibase operational and then we would call back and have the ships sent over. The people running Milan Helibase were under the impression that they would send the ships out to do bucket work and after there fuel cycle would land at Blue Helibase. Before Blue helibase was operational helicopters started coming over to land. This came as a bit of a surprise to us working to get Blue Helibase ready since we did not know they were coming. The pad makers were laid out, but not all of the brush had been taken out of the safety circles. This was one of several things that were not ready when the helicopters started coming. Helicopter xxxx was one of the ships coming into land. The pilot was told to land on pad one and that a marsheller was heading out there. The marsheller got out there about the same time that xxxx was trying to set down his bucket. The marsheller moved out of the way and did not marshel the helicopter down. After the marsheller got out of the way and turned around he notice that the tail of xxxx was close to a bush near the edge of the safety circle. The pilot at this point was looking down as he was landing the ship. So the marsheller was not able to notify the pilot with hand signals. This was when the helicopter was almost down. After the pilot had shut down and got out he notice his tail was just above a juniper bush. At this point the bush was cut out. The helicopter''s mechanic looked at the tail rotor and told the Helicopter Manager that no damage had been done. At about 1330 after flying .8 of an hour it was realized, between the Mechanic and Helicopter Manager, that there had been a green smudge on the tail rotor. At this point the Helibase called Air Attack and had xxxx return to base and shut down. There are several lesson that have been learned. 1. The importance of positive communications 2. Clean all obstructions out of safety circles 3. If Parking Tenders are not giving hand signals they need to be able to communicate via radio with the pilots. Pilot Comments: After helibase radioed that they were ready for me to land, I made my approach into the wind to pad #1. Marshaller was in place. I set water bucket down between the marshaller and the pad marker.I decended down to a 10 ft. hover and looked ahead at the marshaller, he was not marshalling,only standing and watching. He gave no indication of any hazard. I looked down and continued to land. After shutdown, I exited the helicopter and saw a juniper bush under the tail roter. In addition to other contributing factors, such as the helibase not ready to recieve landing helicopters, and the marshaller not giving any hand signals. The landing saftey circle was clearly not adequate for this helicopter. At a minimum the approach and departure path should have been cleared of brush in accordance to the IHOG chapter 8. The 90ft saftey circle is not large enough.If the pad marker is in the middle of the saftey circle and a helicopter lands with the nose on the pad, the tail roter will be outside the saftey circle. I recommend that the IHOG be changed to provide an adequate safey circle. Also, after discussion with helibase manager, I was informed that they were told by the regional helicopter operations specialist, in region 3, that a marshaller was not required, and a parking tender was to be used.

At 1548 on 08/19/2010 while working the Aircraft Desk on the Forest Dispatch office, I received a call from Medford Interagency Dispatch that there is a helicopter enroute to a fire on the Willamette NF.  The helicopter will be flying close to our boundary so they wanted to give us a heads up.  I followed the helicopter on National Flight Following and when the helicopter got close to our forest boundary I advised the Air Attack of the presence of the helicopter.  As the helicopter came farther onto the forest, I called the other dispatch to see if they had contact with the helitanker and was told yes they were talking to the helitanker on National Flight Following. {I could not hear them talking}.  Air Attack was unable to raise the helitanker on either air to air or on National Flight following.  We tried calling the helicopter multiple times also.  While keeping a vigilant look at AFF because of all the aircraft we had in the air at the time, I saw that the helicopter was flying right toward our fire.  I immediately contacted Air Attack on the radio to make sure he had a visual on the helicopter and air attack said he did but still could not raise the Helicopter on Air to Air or NFF. The helicopter flew through our fire and continued flying to the north and then was no longer a safety issue to our aircraft. During this time I was also on the phone with the other dispatch trying to get them to contact the helicopter.  Again, I was told that the aircraft dispatcher had contact with the helicopter.  I informed them that the helicopter was flying right through the Temporary Flight Restriction and was told they would contact the pilot again on the radio.  We did not hear back from the other dispatch.  I told the primary Air Attack about what had happened and he said he would have the Unit Aviation Officer {UAO} contact me.  I told the UAO what had happened and was asked to file a Safecom.

I advised the Unit FMO (Montrose BLM) that aerial supervisionresources for the incident (FS jurisdiction) should be requested in view ofongoing and anticipated tactical use of aviation resources (multipleairtanker missions, one helicopter and expected media interest). While searching for the Benton helispot (I could not locate due to being in new country) we decided to land east of the county equipment yard with 31 minutes of fuel remaining. Later (that day) the pilot indicated that the fuel light came on.Pilot statement:After having been dispatched to a fire in the northern area of our district we were to work an area approx. 5-7 miles west of the Benton BLM helibase.  Not having familiarity of this area I asked the crewmembers where my fuel would be.  One of the crew in the rear of the helicopter pointed to a spot on the horizon as the area of the BLM helibase where my fuel would be.After working the fire I returned to my landing site and informed the XXXXXX. that I needed fuel.  After several minutes, and me once again advising the XXXXXX. that I desperately needed fuel they boarded the helicopter.  I departed the dip site and began a heading toward the area that we had all agreed upon earlier as the BLM helibase.  The XXXXXX pointed to a different location toward downtown Benton.  I re-informed them that we had all discussed the BLM helibase prior to landing to re-configure for the fire and that I was heading for that area.  My fuel truck had not yet arrived at the helibase.The XXXXXXXX advised me that they were quite sure that where we needed to land was at the downtown area of Benton.  I was heading for a spot of trees approx. 4 miles north of Benton.  They  diverted me to the area of downtown Benton stating `they saw the yellow fire trucks at the station`.  I will now note that my VEMD indicated I had 29 minutes of fuel remaining.  This fuel reading is based upon actual fuel flow and is accurate based on this.I now headed for the area that my XXXXXX advised, however I once again pointed north and advised that the BLM base should be north of our location.  They  told me that they were unsure of where the base actually was but they saw fire trucks.  I also now saw the trucks that they had pointed out however saw no landing pad.  I began to orbit the site in downtown Benton and saw that my fuel light began to flicker `on`.  Being somewhat fuel critical and now not having confidence that my XXXXXX knew where we needed to go, I elected to make a safe approach and landing to a dirt road behind the downtown fire station in Benton.  We did land safely and received re-fueling shortly thereafter.  After receiving fuel, I flew to the area north of Benton so as to familiarize myself with the helibase location.

Jumper aircraft dropped 8 jumpers from NCSB on Badger Incident.  The aircraft called at 1847 to say they were in route to Redmond for fuel and asked if we have them on AFF. I stated we did not (I had AFF up but they were not showing). The aircraft said they'd flight follow on local repeater. (We do not have functional national flight follow frequency at our dispatch center.)  I advised the aircraft to call from Redmond via landline once on the ground.  I called Central Oregon dispatch at 1848 to let them know of incoming aircraft but COC had gone out of service.  I called the Redmond Tanker Base - no one there either.  I called Central Washington Dispatch (CWC) to tell them of my concerns regarding aircraft not showing on AFF and no one at COC to receive.  CWC told me the aircraft icon was showing inactive at NCSB.  CWC gave me the tail number, which hadn’t been included on the resource order; for I only knew the call sign of Jumper ___, which CWC had at time of order told me was ___.   I checked - Automated Flight Following which does not have these call signs inputted.   There was no further check-ins received at our dispatch.  At 1914, 25 minutes after last contacted the jump ship, we received a landline call that they planned to lift off from Redmond in 30-45 minutes.  At 1918 we received another landline from the jumper aircraft that they would flight follow with us until they crossed the Columbia River, then flight follow with Wenatchee Dispatch.  At 1946 the jumper aircraft called via landline to say they were in route to Wenatchee and at 1955 the jumper aircraft called our dispatch on local repeater saying they'd made contact with Wenatchee Dispatch.  There was no flight following for this aircraft from 1847 to 1914 due to1) The Aircraft tail designator was not active on AFF (and not able to reflect its call sign)2) The limited range on local repeater3) Our dispatch center has no functioning national flight follow frequency4) It was unknown ahead of time that the jumper aircraft was planning to refuel at Redmond so Central Oregon Dispatch could have been notified before they went out of service.

At 1405 8 August, 2002, T-60 was dispatched to the in Sour Bisquitin fire. Our load was 2550 gallons of retardant and a full load of gas weighing 12,000 pounds. We departed Klamath Falls airort wihich was VFR, but the smoke was heavy in all quadrants. The temperature was in the mid 90's with an attendant high density altitude. Climb peformance was going to be poor as with all heavy piston powered aircraft. Translated, this means the climb rate was going to be marginal at times and fluctuating between zero and three hundred feet per minute for significant stretches of time. The tops of today's smoke layer varied between eitht and ten thousand feet. Obviously, quite a lengthy time is spent flying through this smoke in IFR conditions. When there's no way anyone can tell exactly what the visability is in the smoke, calling the visability acceptable, is a foolish game. Not only that, flying IFR without filing a flight plan, (totally unreasonable) is illegal. When I arrived over the coordinates given me in the dispatch, I was looking into a heavy layer of smoke below me. If the coordinates were a little off, that wasn't the problem. There was a heavy layer of smoke between me and the ground. The drop altitude was below 4000 feet. That was going to require me to descend 4000 feet through the smoke and hope there were no hills or other aircraft in my way. The odds are it could be done, and for that matter, has been done countless times. Where is the plane in front of me coming off his drop?. If I drop, where is the tanker coming in behind me? Sound sily? Think about it. Had I dropped my retardant load, the climb back to altitude would have been faster, but still in IFR conditions. What heading do I take to assure myself of missing the tallest peaks? Can I see them? Maybe. My decision was to stay at altitude(I actually climbed another 1000 feet to have somewhat better visability) and return to Klamath Falls loaded. Any tanker taking the same direct route between Klamath Falls and the fire would have to cope with the same visability problems. As it was, another tanker popped into view so close as to make the passing not much more than luck. The closing speed of two tankers doing 200 knots each is obviously abut 400 knots. Roughly figuring, that's about 700 feet per second closing rate. In the smoke, evasive actin would be moot. My decision was to abort the mission. We are constantly being told not to push a situation or take chances. The reluctance of pilots to follow this advice is evidenced all the time. The reason has as much to do with making money as with the inmachoin can do mentallity. The inSour Bisquitin fire is over 300,000 acres and drops I made days ago are now burried well inside the burn. We are called to drop upon lines where there is no visable ground support nor high priority ground to protect. We pilots are not blind, nor is this something new to behold. We are not building a fireproof wall with the retardant we drop. These few drops made before smoke shuts down the tanker opperation are not critical to the control of a monster fire. I'll gladly argue this point with anyone.

At approximately 1555 we departed Cedar City for a fire east of Price, UT. After takeoff we retracted the gear. The gear would not retract. We cycled the gear several times, it still failed to retract. We jettisoned the load and returned to Cedar City. After landing I visually checked the landing gear and found a bolt line and hard line to emergency air brake system had come loose. After further checking the landing gear systems I found the landing gear hydraulic down line lever had been engaged. This system had not been used all season nor in previous seasons. I asked my co-pilot and mechanics if they had set the lever or worked on the air line. They stated they had not. I have no explanation of how or who engaged the lever or removed the air line fittings.

On August 18, 2000, while retrieving a paracargo deployment bag, the static line became wedged between the rear ramp door and the fuselage of the aircraft.  The location was approximately 3 feet aft of the left jump door, under the plane where the fuselage and the rear ramp door meet forming a seam.  Apparently, while pulling in the static line and deployment bag, the static line wedged into the seam and could not be removed.  This was the last cargo drop of the mission.  After conferring with the pilot, the spotter cut the static line, leaving approximately two feet of line at the wedge point.  The trailing two feet of static line and deployment bag continued to stay wedged in the ramp door seam until it was removed on the ground in Afton, WY.The location of the wedged static line and deployment bag never compromised the safe operation of the aircraft during the incident.

8/8/02 Long Mesa Fire at Mesa Verde NP, CO. Fire status - contained and being managed by Type 3 organization after transition from Type 2 team. At approximately 1500 on 8/8/02 I was approached by the Type 3 Operations Section Chief requesting that I deploy a three-person helitack crew and begin bucket operations to mop up some inpolitical smokesin within the perimiter of the Long Mesa Fire. As we discussed the mission I became concerned that this mission fell into the category of inis this flight necessary? As this question was being asked to OPS he became very defensive and felt we were refusing a mission. Several attempts were made to clarify our concerns. I attempted to outline a risk analysis for the OPS and determine what the best course of action might be. My concerns were that we were being asked to deploy personnel on spots that OPS stated were no threat to the line and perform bucket work on those same spots. As the conversation continued the OPS Chief stated that if we did not want to do it he would get another crew to take care of it. I tried to explain that it was not just a concern for this crew, but for any personnel placed in a hazardous area only to be mopping up interior inpoliticalin smokes (other hazards: terrain, snags, etc.) We came up with several options for the risk analysis, but these were all rejected by OPS since we questioned his original mission. I was not convinced that this was an overly hazardous mission, I just felt it was a proposed mission that needed further discussion to come up with other options or actions to mitigate hazards.

Returning from the Burnt Canyon Fire near Terra, Utah, Tanker 139 was directed to land at Hill AFB Airtanker Base. The displaced threshold was properly marked.  1000 feet and 1500 feet before the displaced threshold were two temporary barricades, the first at 1500 feet from the displaced threshold is made of cinderblocks spaced about 10 feet apart with plastic stantions tied together by a rope and the second barricade 1000 feet from the displaced threshold is a continous line of 6 inch by 6 inch landscaping timbers with road barricades lying on the sides with strobe lights at about 10 foot intervals. The pilot held the nose off the runway and hit the line of landscaping timbers with the 56 inch diameter right main tire.  Several strobe lights and road barricades were destroyed.  Inspection of the aircraft revealed only a minor dent in the lower aft fuselage possabley caused by debris from the cinder block.  The large diameter main wheel did not appear to be damaged.  The officials at Hill AFB inspected the damage to the runway barricades and to the aircraft. On 8-10-2018 helicopter Nxxx piloted by xx xx departed xx Helibase located at xx airstrip for its second cycle of the day. At approximately 18:11 the DC Buss circuit breaker tripped causing the loss of the avionics including the FM and Victor radios. After completing one high altitude circle diagnosing the problem and resetting the breaker, the breaker tripped again and Nxxx returned to Helibase. Fearing the AFF and communication radios were lost simultaneously and that emergency response activities were beginning, the pilot utilized the hand held BK radio to establish contact with the Helibase on the deck frequency. Nxxx requested the Helibase to communicate to air attack the issue and that they were returning to Helibase. Upon landing at Helibase the system came back on normally with no sign of faults. Nxxx departed Helibase on a test flight back towards the fire and the breaker immediately tripped again. Nxxx landed at Helibase and went out of service. After hours servicing found that the vibrations encountered during translational lift caused a metal avionics component which is shock mounted to get too close to a circuit breaker on the DC Buss causing the trip. Clearance was increased, insulation was added to the circuit breaker to fix the issue.

We were dispatched to a fire on the Sequoia NF from the San Bernardino Airtanker Base. Just prior to arrival at the fire, we were cancelled by the air attack at the fire. The ATS on board the aircraft was scheduled to return to his home duty station the next day and his vehicle was at the Fresno Airtanker Base. After conferring with dispatch, it was decided that we would recover to Fresno to facilitate getting the ATS to his vehicle for the return trip to Redding. After receiving the order to land at Fresno, I obtained the current weather for FAT. Due to drift smoke from fires in the bay area, the visibilities were varying at FAT and at the time of our arrival, they were were just below VFR minimums. I contacted approach control and requested an IFR clearance into Fresno. I received a clearance and approach began vectoring us for an ILS approach to runway 29R. I proceeded to set up the avionics and loaded the approach into the GPS````s. During this phase of the flight we had excellent ground contact/visibility and what appeared to be much greater than a few miles of forward visibility. After getting established on the inbound course I recognized that I did not have a glideslope indication. We were approaching the point at which we should begin to intercept the glideslope and begin the decent phase. While I was trying to figure out why the glidesope indication was missing I allowed my altitude to vary and began a decent. I still had good visual contact with the ground and was beginning to pick up the airport environment. The approach controller alerted me to my altitude being lower than it should have been for my location and i began to correct back to the proper altitude. While climbing back to the required altitude I realized I had bumped a required selector pad {on the gps touchscreen} one too many times which was the cause for the glideslope missing. I corrected the selection to VLOC and all indications were proper. We followed the approach with no further issue and landed on the selected runway. Shortly after we parked at the tanker base we were dispatched to a fire just southeast of the airport and the visibility had risen back to VFR and we departed under VFR conditions. After operating at the fire, the airport had dropped back just below VFR minimums and we requested another IFR approach clearance and completed that approach with no issues and it was end of the duty day when we parked at the base. I was remiss in not filing a safecom in a more timely manner and should have made formal notification to share my experience with the appropriate individuals. My ability to see the terrain and the airport environment at the time of the event inappropriately lessened my concern about my mistake{s} and deviation from the proper altitude for the profile being flown.

A near miss occurred between a SEAT and a helicopter with a bucket on a 100 foot longline. Air Attack {Nxxxx}had just transitioned with the initial ATGS {Nxxxx}, the helicopters were supporting ground operations on the west and east ends of the left flank (north side). The fire was aligned west to east with a prevailing west to SW wind. Retardant operations were happening in the middle zone of the left flank. The each helicopter had their own water dip site, one was a ½ mile north of the left flank on the west end, and the orher was one mile south of the east end of the fire. During the air attack transition 2 SEAT drops were made, but the relief air attack did not see the south side helicopter make actual water drops in its’ area of work. Soon after the ATGS transition a third SEAT {T-xxx} arrived and was cleared into the FTA. The air attack intended to instruct both helicopters {Nxxxx & Nxxxx}to hold but evidently called twice to the north side helicopter {Nxxxx}. The south side helicopter {Nxxxx} pilot heard the calls and did not think the hold was for him because he thought the tanker ops would be on the west side of the fire. The air attack did not catch the mistaken hold call to the south side helicopter when the north side helicopter pilot replied to the second hold call that he had already said he was holding and had not recieved a hold confimation from the south side helicopter. The SEAT pilot had seen both helicopters during his arrival on scene depart the fire for the dip sites. When he heard the call for the helicopters to hold at the dip, he thought the line was clear. We recently purchased two Red Dragon aerial ignition machines and had some issues when we used them for the first time. First, we installed the exit chute incorrectly so that the spheres could not drop out. We had placed one of the securing nuts on the inside instead of both being on the outside which caused the chute to be misaligned. Unfortunately we bench tested without the chute so were not aware of our mistake until the PSD operator experienced a jam. He attempted to clear it manually and noticed smoke coming from the machine. He immediately activated the emergency water system which extinguished the fire, and the helicopter returned to the helispot, where we discovered our mistake. After correcting our error the machine worked fine for a fuel cycle. During the next fuel cycle, however, the PSD operator experienced 3 jams in one chute. The first time, he was not able to clear the jam and the aircraft returned to the helibase where we were not able to duplicate or solve the jam. We were aware of the jamming issue caused by removing the hopper and then not removing the two spheres that block the chutes when this occurs: this was not what had occurred in this case. The aircraft returned to the unit where firing continued until he experienced two more jams in succession. He was able to manually clear both jams and complete ignition. Upon examining a random sample of Dragon Eggs, we discovered several spheres had a sharp, jagged piece of plastic protruding from the seam area. We had noticed a large number of shavings in the hopper and wondered if some of these protrusions broke off while the spheres were agitated in the hopper. We suspected that these hard plastic protrusions might be causing the eggs to jam in the chute.

On July 7th at approximately 1600 during the second cycle of a water dropping mission on the fire, the pilot received an indication of a measurable gas temperature {mgt} exceedance on the diamond j 61000-092 mgt gauge. Thunderstorms began to encroach on the fire and the pilot informed air attack he needed to retrieve the crew and return to the helibase. After returning to the helibase, the pilot discovered the mgt gauge indicated that a mgt exceedance had occurred, 6 degrees for 37 seconds. The Diamond j mgt gauge does not confirm an exceedance has occurred until the aircraft is shut-down. After the crew had completed an AAR of the initial attack, the pilot notified the Manager/COR of the exceedance and that the aircraft was out of service until an inspection of the “hot section” of the engine could be performed. Notification of the exceedance occurred an hour after the aircraft had returned to the helibase. Pilot’s account of the incident: during the flight, I did notice that the mgt gauge flashed and then stop flashing. This can happen if the temperature reaches a warning point. Typically, the flash would be accompanied by an aural warning, however, the aircraft is not wired for the aural warning. If there is no exceedance, the gauge will then stop flashing once corrective action is taken. The gauge will also flash if an actual exceedance occurs, but then stops after a minute. Without the gauge flashing and without having seen the actual moment of exceedance, the next time the pilot has an indication is when the shuts down at the end of the flight the gauge starts to flash again. I’m assuming the exceedance occurred while drafting water or during climb out, and that I saw the last couple of flashes on the gauge. Weather started to get worse and I chose to stop water dropping ops and pick up the crew to return to helibase.  Once on the ground, I did confirm that an exceedance had occurred. Research was done to determine the next steps and the Manager was notified.

On Thursday July 10th, at approximately 1700 I witnessed the helicopter release water from his bucket while flying above his helipad at the 25 mile helibase after returning from fire suppression on the 25 mile creek fire. I am certain the release of water was intentional because the water that was released came out the bottom of the bucket.  In addition to the water releasing from the bottom of the bucket, the flight path from the water source to the fire had been altered during this drop.  I had been watching the aircraft for about 45 when I watched the aircraft deviate it`s flight path towards the helibase and over top of the landing pad.  At the time of the drop I knew I was going to get wet from the water because the wind was blowing up slope towards my direction.  Although I did not receive a direct hit during the drop, it was enough where I turned my back and covered the ipad I was holding at the time of the drop.  At the time of the drop the bucket was approximately 50 feet above and approximately 50 feet down slope from my position and 100 feet above the landing pad.  In addition to witnessing this drop I also felt that the pilot was flying at a very low altitude while in route to and from the fire area.  At times it appeared to me that the bucket was only 50 to 100 feet above the terrain, power lines and/or trees while the helicopter was climbing from the dip site in route to the fire area.

Air patrol departed the airport at 1326 in a Cessna 182 under contract with the US Forest Service. The aircraft contained agency carded pilot and an aerial observer. They were approximately 1.5 hours into the patrol flight when they heard a “pop” in the forward engine compartment. The engine began running roughly. The pilot adjusted engine controls and trim and then proceeded to diagnose the problem. Engine oil began to cover the front windscreen of the aircraft. The pilot issued a mayday call over the radio. The pilot and observer began to assess and discuss potential landing areas for emergency landing. They selected a pasture in river drainage as their best option and began a gliding descent. Engine oil continued to completely cover the windscreen while descending. They had sufficient altitude and airspeed for a single pass by the pasture to scan for hazards. They set up for a 180 degree approach turn to a landing heading and began to lose some airspeed and altitude A large tree in the center of the field was identified as an obstacle they would have to avoid. Winds were gusty and variable generally from the west.  The crew was not able to identify wind direction. They turned for final approach to the East,  and the wind was at their tail. The pilot added some remaining power to clear the tree and noticed a power line he needed to descend under to avoid it.  They cleared the tree and descended under the power line touching the ground just past the power line. They bounced upon impact. The front landing gear was torn off upon the second touchdown. They began to slide on the rear landing gear and nose of the airplane,  the right wing impacting the ground. They continued to skid nearly straight until coming to a halt 75 to 100 yards from the tree line at the end of the pasture at approximately 47 38.948N latitude, 115 59.912W longitude at elevation of 2377 msl. The occupants of the aircraft emerged with bruising on their arms and sore backs and necks from the forward and lateral forces in the cockpit after impact.Damage was determined to be substantial and the accident is currently under investigation by the NTSB

With the helicopter shut down the 100' longline was attached to the bellyhook to fly a 72-gal. blivet to fire Q718. The release mechanisms for the bellyhook and remote hook were checked and functioning. The helicopter then started and lifted off. At about 5' AGL the electrical cord came undone inferring that tension was being placed on the electrical cord. At about 10 to 15' AGL the cable fell to the ground. The pilot landed and the mechanic/fuel truck driver inspected the components and found no damage. The longline was reattached, checked and the load flown to the fire without incident. Problem: When the helitack person hooked up the longline to the helicopter he may have pulled in too much slack resulting in a bow being placed on the cable between the hook and the ground. The built-up tension in the bow of the cable probably caused the cable to twist up laterally resulting in the pear ring slipping over the tip of the hook and past the security gate.

August 2, 2003To Whom It May Concern:	This letter is written to document an event involving ground resources and an airtanker.	Recently, the Pagosa Ranger District endured a lightning bust, which caused multiple ignitions over a 3-4 day period.  Precipitation on the zone contributed to a low spread potential in the fine fuels, although there was, and still is, a high probability of ignition and spread component in the heavy fuels.   	As district personnel coordinated initial attack on multiple ignitions in the Ant Hill area, with the assistance of county and local fire district resources, air attack arrived on scene.  Air attack was dispatched by Durango Interagency Dispatch Center.  Radio traffic between Durango Dispatch, air attack, and ground personnel staffing fires made radio communication difficult.  At the time, District personnel, with the assistance of county and city resources, were initial attacking three fires, one of which was East Ant Hill, located on Forest Service land.  Neither district personnel nor ground resources ordered air attack, and district personnel only realized air attack was on scene after air attack arrived and indicated the fire location.	Initial attack personnel began working on the East Ant Hill fire and determined that a tree on fire had to be felled.  Coordination had been made with the local fire department, which was taking action on a nearby fire on private land.         As all of these events were occurring, and in addition to the district answering calls from the public and dispatching resources to other fires, we overheard air attack request a heavy air tanker.  No district or ground personnel, as we discovered later, had been contacted about the retardant drop.  The IC on the ground tried to call air attack on forest net and air-to-ground, with no success.  Fire staff in the office also tried to contact air attack on forest net, with no success.  We were trying to determine air attack’s intentions, all the while trying to coordinate efforts elsewhere.During this activity, the sawyer on the East Ant Hill fire had placed a face cut on his tree, and began his back cut.  The sawyer felled the tree and began bucking up the top portion of the tree, which was on fire.  The remainder of the IA squad was clear of the felling operation, but started back to assist the feller after the tree was on the ground.  These personnel saw the sawyer drop his saw on the ground and begin to run from the area.  He commented to me that “After dropping the tree, which was on a knoll surrounded by flatter ground, he looked up and saw, at eye level, an air tanker coming in on him so he ran out of the way”.  Apparently, the air tanker pilot saw the tree fall and was able to abort the drop, even though he was on low-level approach.  If the drop had occurred minutes/seconds earlier, the pilot would not have seen the sawyer under the tree.  With the tree already being cut, the retardant drop could have caused the tree to fall in a direction other than the intended lay, which could have caused serious injury, or worse, to the sawyer and/or other crewmembers.  Later, it was determined that part of the retardant drop was intended for a fire on private land, which consisted of a burning fence post.  The local fire department did not want retardant applied on private land.  The other target was the East Ant Hill fire.  However, the IC was not aware that retardant would be dropped on this fire. The following day, immediate action was taken by the Forest and District FMO.  A detailed, formal After Action Review is planned.  Issues that need to be addressed include;1.   The forest radio system easily becoming overloaded with traffic, and poor performance of the radio system overall, especially during inclement weather.2.	Personnel not directly working local fires saturating the forest net with conversation.3.	Air resources arriving on scene and executing actions without first contacting ground forces or district fire staff.4.	Multiple decision makers, both in the air and at Durango Dispatch Center, who are unaware of local weather, a fire’s resistance to control efforts, resources in the local area, or local coordination with private landowners and local fire departments.5.	Lack of adherence to LCES.  If communication is not established with ground resources, or at a minimum with district fire staff, all actions should cease.

While on a fire mission after flying approximately 1.3hrs and completing 12 tank drops, we started to hear a “buzzing” sound from the forward transmission. All indications inside the cockpit were indicating normal. As we were coming out of the dip, I looked at the hydraulic pressure gauges and noticed the {#}1 flight hydraulic pressure gauge was starting to decrease to approximately 2400PSI {3000 PSI- normal operating pressure}. We dumped our load of water and almost immediately after that the Master Caution Panel {#}1 Hyd Press caution light illuminated and the pressure on the gauge went to zero. We then turned on the {#}1 PTU and the pressure returned to 3000PSI on the gauge for about 3 seconds. The pressure then dropped to zero again. We notified Air Attack that we had a {#}1 flight hydraulics failure and that we would be returning to helibase. Was about a 7-minute flight back to helibase due to the fact that there were no other landing options in the area we were working in other than the trees. {#}2 Flight Hyd pressure was rock steady through flight back to service. Landed with no other problems.

Both declined immediate medical attention and the elderly woman received stitches (#13) from her health care provider. The area was declared clear prior to use and crowd control measures were in place. After this event, the pilot returned to the pond and took another load and departed without any further safety issues. The following statement was from the pilot: ''''On 06 August @ approximately 1800 during a dip of water I started take off. We had more water than I felt I needed during take off. Prior to leaving the pond & crossing over land, I elected to release the load for safety reasons due to a crowd in the departure flight path. With the water gone, I returned to the pond and took another load of water. Take off was completed with no further issues.'''' A current risk analysis concludes that all water point operations will cease except during fires when the facility is vacated.

Near mid-air report: 7 August, time 1855, left downwind runway 35 at 1,000 feet AGL, at the Airport.  Aircraft involved were Lead “A” and Air Attack “B” both working fires near the airport.  Estimated near miss separation distance was 100 to 200feet.  Narrative: There were two Initial Attack fires in close proximity - Fire “AA”, less than 1 Nautical Mile {NM} east of the Airport using 2 SEATs, 1 T2 Helicopter, 2 State DC-7’s, with Aerial Support provided by Lead “A” and Air Attack “A”.  The second Fire “BB” was 7 NM northwest of the Airport using 1 SEAT, 3 Heavy Air-tankers with Aerial Support provided by Lead “B” and Air Attack “B”.  Each Fire Traffic Area {FTA} had its own distinct Air-Air VHF frequency assigned.  Additional “non-players” to the FTA and airport traffic pattern, at about the time of incident, were a medevac helicopter {Life-Link} enroute to the hospital and an unannounced Type1 Helicopter prepositioning to the airport.  The FTA pattern for Fire AA was exactly coincident with a left traffic pattern for runway 35 at the airport.  Both Leads A and B were periodically monitoring each respective VHF frequencies.  Lead B coordinated with Lead A on how to sequence Fire BB’s SEAT aircraft into the airport traffic pattern to Load retardant and Return to the fire.  Lead A directed a standard Left downwind entry to runway 35 at or below 4,300 feet: which was 500feet below the flight pattern Lead A was flying on Fire AA.  This was working well with the SEAT from Fire BB.  At approximately 1845 Air Attack B left Fire BB for a fuel stop at the airport. He flew 10 NW to the west of the airport and turned back east to set up for landing.  Air Attack B contacted Air Attack A to advise of intentions to enter Fire AA’s FTA and land at the airport.  Air Attack A acknowledged that Air Attack B was inbound for the airport to get fuel.  There was no acknowledgement from Air Attack B that he had received the transmission from Air Attack A.  At that time Air Attack A was sending the acknowledgement, Air Attack B was picking up the call from the inbound Life-Link on Unicom and was concerned for his safety inbound to Fire AA’s FTA.  Radio traffic was very heavy at the time. Air Attack A assumed that Air Attack B would switch to Unicom and that all aircraft were monitoring that frequency.  Lead A was unaware Air Attack B was inbound for fuel because he was monitoring both FTA VHF frequencies and not Unicom.  In hindsight, the communication loop was not completely closed between the two Air Attacks: however Air Attack B switched over to Unicom and announced intentions to join the airport traffic pattern.  At approximately 1855 both Lead A and Air Attack B unknowingly converged and saw each other in very close proximity on a Left downwind for runway 35 at 4,700-4,800 MSL.  It was the classic high wing below and low wing above pass over where both aircraft took evasive action. Both pilots in Lead A do not recall getting a separate TCAS advisory on Air Attack B.  There were many aircraft actively running on the ground at the airport resulting in the TCAS screen being flooded with overlapping symbology.  Air Attack B does recall receiving a separate TCAS alert and was immediately outside scanning.

Airplane was conducting a Fire detection/reconnaissance mission over the Gila NF. Approximately one hour into the flight the Pilot began to notice issues with the left engine and inconsistent RPMs. Pilot was unable to properly adjust and maintain consistent RPMs for the left engine. Pilot began to trouble shoot issue in flight, with all gauges showing in normal ranges. The prop governor for the left engine was suspected as faulty. The mission was aborted and crew returned to Grant County Airport without incident. The cowling for the left engine was removed for inspection, and the linkage for the prop governor was found to be disconnected from the governor. All the parts were found in the bottom of the engine cowling. It appeared that the keeper pin was inserted into the linkage nut but was not bent over to secure the nut and the nut vibrated loose in flight. Both engines for this aircraft were recently rebuilt, and it is assumed that the company did not connect the linkage properly. There was no obvious mechanical failure of any of the linkage parts upon inspection.

The Pilot and I were at 7500 ft. directly over the Boulevard Fire No. 271.  We were flying right-hand turns.  At 1135 hrs, a Meyer 200 fixed wing aircraft passed directly over the top of us, flying west to east in a straight line, at approximately 8500 ft.  We could not get an identity number for the aircraft.  We tried to contact the aircraft on 122.9AM, we received no response.  We continued our Air Attack mission. The intrusion was not a critical safety factor.  Our Air Attack platform was the only aircraft in the area.  It was, however, a violation of the Temporary Flight Restriction which had been in place the afternoon of the day before (09/01/01).  The T.F.R. was established as a 3 mile radius at, and below, 9000 ft MSL.  My Pilot and I agreed the Meyer aircraft was definitely below 9000 ft MSL.

The pilot said it was probably just water coming off the deck, but he would watch it. About a minute later the pilot called back that it had not stopped and he was returning to helibase. On the afternoon of August 19th we were requested to Div A on the Lake Fire to support El Toro slowing down some fire pushing towards their dozer line.  When we arrived on scene Air Attack was over head and briefed us that the Scoopers X and Y were also working in the same area and that H-XXX a CH-47 would be joining us.  He briefed us about the Scoopers flight path, their check points, as well as the dip site (Castaic Lake) and the check point (Wires Check) we would be using.  We had flown in Div A several times and were familiar with the routes and checkpoints.  After several drops working with the Scoopers and helicopter, air attack announced that he would be departing and that it would be 10-15 minutes before the replacement air attack got on station.  The outgoing air attack checked with the scoopers and both helicopters working in Div A about their comfort level working together without air attack overhead.  All were ok with it and continued operating.  The outgoing air attack had mentioned he had an inbound tanker but the tanker was instructed to hold until the new air attack got into place and the new air attack would direct the tanker.  
We made a couple drops and we had noticed the tanker holding above the fire.  Inbound to the drop when we announced “Wires Check” I noticed the tankers holding pattern had shifted slightly.  We continued inbound and tried to raise air attack.  We got no response from air attack and started to turn out from the area checking the tankers flight path.  The Tanker began turning in our direction and we noticed on our ADS-B traffic display that the tanker was descending and coming in over the top of us.  We continued our altered flight path and watched the tanker continue onto the drop in the same vicinity that we had been dropping water.  A few moments later being downwind of the flight path we encountered the wake turbulence from the tanker.  We again tried to reach air attack but weren’t able to make contact.  
Checking that the area was clear we continued to the drop and returned to the dip site.  We notified the scoopers and H-XXX to be on the look out and that we had a tanker drop nearby that was unannounced.  After getting another bucket and checking in at the “Wire Check” we were finally able to reach air attack and he briefed us that he had another tanker on the drop and to hold.
We briefed the air attack that the previous tanker was brought in without our knowledge and we needed positive communication if tankers were going to be working in the same area.  He responded that we had stepped on him when he made the call.
The new air attack had mentioned several times over the radio that this was his first time on the fire, he did not get a good transition, and had got a late dispatch to the incident.  
The only instruction we got from air attack was to stay at our below 5000 ft.  
Helicopters operate low to the ground especially in the dip sites and can’t always receive radio transmissions in the low canyon dip sites.  Air Attack may have made a call for us to hold at the Wires Check but we didn’t receive it.  Hold instructions need to be confirmed by the aircraft required to hold.

On 8/21/20018 at approximately 14:00 during a routine fuel transfer, a fuel truck was over filled and spilled approximately 15 gallons of Jet A fuel onto the roadway adjacent to the Helibase property on the Boyd’s Fire Incident. The fuel truck driver using a measuring stick and fuel logs as a guide assumed that the fuel truck could receive 1800 gallons of fuel and failed to visually verify that the amount of fuel entering the tank was within the tank’s capacity. As a result, the 2500-gallon capacity of the fuel truck was exceeded resulting in an overflow of fuel out the top port of the fuel tank. The fuel truck driver immediately reversed flow on the pump and placed absorbent towels on the spill {area 10ft x 15ft}, cleaning as much material as possible off the gravel surface of the roadway. All contaminated material was collected by the fuel tender, placed in a hazmat container and brought back to the fueling facility for disposal. The fuel truck driver then returned to duty without notifying the helicopter manager or Helibase Manager {HEB2}. At 18:00 the land owner notified the Air Support Group Supervisor {ASGS} that there was a large fuel spill on the property and requested that no more fuel be spilled on the property. The ASGS immediately notified the HEB2 and HMGB who then met with the fuel driver and pilot to gather information and inspect the spill site {Note: The AOBD was notified at this time}. The ASGS and AOBD then inspected the spill site and relayed back to the HEB2 and HMGB their expectations on how to mitigate any further issues with fuel transfers.

A SEAT was dispatched to a smoke near the MT/CO boarder. At around 1640, T-xxx contacted the Dispatch Center to report a fire. T-xxx could see some vehicles on the ground but they looked like private personnel. T-xxx recommended a drop on the fire. Dispatch asked T-xxx to standby so we could contact the County to confirm that they had engines on scene. Also, asked if T-xxx was IA Carded, which he confirmed. Dispatch was in contact with the county IC when T-xxx called back recommending a SEAT drop to control the head of the fire. Dispatch again asked T-xxx to standby until we confirmed with the IC on the ground and gave him the frequency to contact BLM fire personnel on the ground. The County IC confirmed that they had some engines and personnel on the ground and they would take the load of retardant. At 1658, T-xxx called back that he did not have radio communications with the ground and reconfirmed frequency, he then stated that he would drop on the East side of the fire to slow the spread. The BLM engine was in the process of putting the frequency in the radio when the SEAT made his first drop. The next transmission that Dispatch received was at 1700 and T-xxx was headed back for a load and return. Dispatch then called the IC back and asked if he would need a Load and Return and that it would be about a 48min to 1 hour turn around time. The IC was okay with the load and return. On the return flight Dispatch had contact with T-xxx at 1738 to reconfirm the frequency. Dispatch tried again to contact T-xxx at 1756 and received a negative contact. At 1800 T-xxx called and said that he had made his second drop and was headed back to tanker base to hold. During this time there was no contact with Dispatch to let us know that the SEAT had contact with the fire or was preparing to drop. However, talking to the BLM engine after the fact, they were in contact with the SEAT for the second drop. A contributing factor was the assignment of an A/G frequency from one of several versions that had been sent out and then changed over the last couple of months. Thus the reason the BLM engine had to field program in that frequency.

Air Attack 430 was scheduled for relief by Air Attack 07 at 1730 over the incident when South Operations ordered AA-07 to respond to the Creek Incident in Tuolomme County. Sierra ECC advised the GACC of the relief required over Musick Incident.  South Zone GACC ordered SNF ECC to send them and they would replace AA-07 with another Air Attack.  Air Operations Director was never consulted and the replacement air attack did not arrive for approximately 40 minutes which forced Air Attack 430 to exceed the 7 hour CDF flight time policy limitation by about 13 minutes.  Personnel assigned on Division U were at a critical support both for communications and for retardant drops which AA-430 canceled due to lack of aerial supervision.  430 grounded fixed wings and returned to Fresno.  AA-430 had Helicopter Coordinator launched to supervise rotor wing until AA-410 arrived. While the need for an air attack was evident for the Creek Incident, and the diversion of the AA-07 solved that problem it caused a situation where aviation management was compromised over the Musick Incident. It is unknown as to the time that the Air Attack order was received by the GACC for the Creek Incident. It is unknown whether AA-410 could have been sent directly to that incident even though it was farther (approx. 15 minutes more flight time) to the Creek Incident than the Fresno based AA-07.  This would have possibly avoided the situation.  Rarely does the South Operations consult with or check with incident management personnel before they move assigned aircraft around to meet other incident needs or to anticipate the negative outcomes of those decisions.  In this case there were ground personnel who were in a hazardous situation that needed fixed wing and close support.  Incident management personnel were not afforded the opportunity to provide this information which could have caused a different response.

The AOBD````s developed a notification procedure to inform each incident helibase of aviation operations in this common space. On July 15, each incident ICS 220 had special instructions directing the helibase managers to inform each other when aircraft were launched to the vicinity of this common space which was identified by latitude and longitude. The information to be provided was aircraft tail number, mission type, and frequency to be used. On July 16, two water scoopers were ordered by the Spicer ATGS to deliver water to the Spicer Fire. The water source for the water scoopers was Fish Lake which was within the common space. A fixed wing performing another mission landed at the airstrip next to the adjacent fire````s helibase and informed them that the water scoopers were using Fish Lake. No resource from the Spicer Fire had notified the adjacent fire````s helibase following the established protocol. The AOBD and ASGS subsequently informed the adjacent fire that the Spicer Fire did have water scoopers drawing water from Fish Lake.BLM Aviation Safety,WS,7/24: The two Fire Bosses were dispatched from Galena to the Spicer fire.

During bucket deployment training, a quarter inch (1/4) hole was noticed in the fuselage.  The hole is located on the rightside, 9 1/2 inches forward from the edge of the rear step, at the base of the fuselage curvature.  The Pre-use inspection  did not reveal the damage (hole).  An examination of the hole and what previous helicopter activities occurred prior to the hole discovery, indicated the damage may have occured during rappel recurrency.  The thumbscrew allenhead on the Sky Genie matches the diameter of the hole.  Various mockup simulations failed to indicate any situation that could indisputably be determined to have caused the damage.  It is theorized that the damage may possibly be attributed to one of the following actions:1) Approaching the aircraft with rope bag with genie on top, the bag was swung into the fuselage with enough force to cause the damage.2) Genie struck side of ship if rappeller swung unnaturally beneath ship.The damage is basically cosmetic, and the contractor has sealed it with tape temporaily, and will do a permanent fix at he first opportunity.

Helicopter XXX {XXX Helitack} and YYY {YYY Helitack} were both dispatched to the Mercur Fire. Air Attack was able to talk to both aircraft on the assigned VHF-AM frequency. In addition, Air Attack could talk to the Incident Commander on the assigned VHF-FM air-to-ground frequency which had a transmit tone of 100.0. However, as both helitack crews engaged in the suppression operations, Air Attack was not able to communicate {after several attempts} with the helitack crew of XXX. A radio check with the YYY helitack crew confirmed that the correct A-G frequency {w/ Tx tone}. After removing the tone from the air-to-ground frequency, Air Attack successfully communicated with the XXX Helitack crew which had already engaged in the suppression of the fire. It is critical that suppression resources ensure that they use the assigned frequencies for an incident. Without ensuring positive communication with all aircraft on the assigned frequency {including the Tx Tone}, the helitack crew should not have actively engaged in suppression action on the fire: air attack was not able to communicate with them in the event of an emergency or critical change in fire behavior.

On Saturday 7/9/2011 there was a loss of communication between an exclusive use helicopter for the Okefenokee refuge and the Helibase that the aircraft was flight following with. The Helicopter was on a mapping mission for the Honey Prairie fire. Do to the loss of communication a search for the aircraft was initiated. According to AFF the aircraft could have been on the pad Bergansa helipad at Dixon Memorial state park. Air attack went to this location and found that the aircraft was indeed on the ground with no problems. The pilot had closed out with the refuge dispatch but not with the fire dispatch.

Aircraft was being refueled by a new refueler.  The pilot followed behind and checked each fuel cap after the refueler filled each tank.  After checking the first 3 tanks manually, the pilot observed the 4th cap visually and determined that the cap was locked in place.  On climb out, the pilot looked to the left to determine that the area was clear.  It was at this time that the pilot noticed the fuel cap was dangling from the tank inlet on its chain.  The pilot then came back in and landed without incident.  The pilot then reattached the fuel cap and continued mission.

We mis-calculated the flight time from the Bitter Creek Fire to the Santa Fe Airport. Distance is 75 kt miles. Resulted in landing at 24 minutes after sunset in single engine aircraft. Contributing factor was an unexpected 50 knot headwind.

While attempting to drop on Tom's Canyon fire, doors on drop system failed to open or close properly.  Jettisoned load in designated jettison area and returned to Grand Junction Tanker Base.  Vendor mechanics checked system and found 2 of the electrical wires which supply power to the hydraulic system had failed.  Repairs were made by vendor mechanics.  Returned to Service by vendor at 0700 on 3 July 1999.

During an initial attack flight, 10 miles out from the incident, the pilot noticed a right fuel boost pump caution panel light illuminated. A precautionary landing was determined necessary, Air Attack was notified of problem and landing location. We landed in an open field close to a road to determine the problem. After landing the pilot pulled left circuit breaker to confirm no fuel pressure on right fuel pump. After consulting the flight manual the crew off loaded and the pilot flew back to base for repair.

Calls by the RAMP mgr, and base radio was made to notify T-XX his gear was not down. A last attempt was called to T-XX to ``abort, abort, abort gear is up`` call was made. The tanker responded and a gear up landing was adverted. The aircraft was reported to have been 10 feet or less over the runway. After the the next landing, T-XX was asked if he needed a break and his response was he was all right and continued operations.
